div.p: LONDON, Printed for John Sturton, at the Middle-Temple-Gate, in Fleestreet, 1697.
PLAYS Lately Publish'd, Timoleon, or the Revolution, a Tragi-Comedy. The Roman Bride, a Tragedy. The Old Batchelor, a Comedy, by Mr. Congreve. Love's a Jest, by Mr. Motte • x. Printed for J. Sturton.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: THIS Play not having answer'd the Ends of my Writing it, the Reader I presume may reasonably expect that (according to Custom) I shou'd endeavour to demonstrate that they who dislik'd it are either Fools, or Poets: Now my sole dependance being the Judgment of an Audience, 'twere madness in me to provoke 'em. And I may with more safety, and less trouble, perswade 'em into a good opinion of their sense, than my own. 'Tis dangerous to Quarrel with a whole Town, as 'tis difficult to please 'em; there is no Appealing to Apollo's Court, after an Illegal Sentence from them, their Will is Law, and 'tis but reasonable it shou'd be so, since they pay for their Power.

I am willing to stand to my Prayer in my Prologue, and to acknowledge it has had a Favourable Fate: I intended (but I had some considerable Hinderances, which the Reader shall know presently) to have made the Town some amends in this Play for their Extraordinary Favours to my First: For I am so far from that vanity of thinking my self Considerable enough to have receiv'd any Prejudice from my Enemies, that I am ready to acknowledge 'twas want of Merit in the Play, not understanding in its Audience, that made it meet with no Kinder Reception. All I propose is to lay down some Excuses why it is not more deserving. But tho' I am ready to confess its defects, yet I wou'd willingly be thought able to mend them.
My first Hindrance was my want of time; for rather than lose a Winter (the Profits of my other being so considerable) I forc'd my self to invent a Fable: Now my first was Spontaneous, and consequently more easie: The one was the Kindly Product of my Fancy, this of my Judgment: (I mean of that little judgment I have) That was a Cherry gather'd in July; this was meerly ripned by Artifice in April, 'twill hardly admit of a Dispute, which must of consequence have the more Natural and Pleasing Taste.

Another Hindrance was my too nice observation of Regularity (which tho' I pretend not exactly to have follow'd, yet perhaps I am something nearer than most of our late Comedies) the Scene never breaking in any Act but the Third, and then not to an unreasonable distance, nor without a necessitous Occasion: The time I think is obviously comprehended in five Hours. But this Confinement is a great Hinderance to Variety of Incidents, which provided they are natural after they are brought in, I think may very reasonably divert us, without observing that strictness. And tho' I am ready to grant that a good Play is much the better for being Regular, yet on the other side, it must be allow'd a Double Art and Labour to make it both Regular and Diverting, and of the two, truly I don't see but men of the greatest sense had rather have their Fancies pleas'd, than their judgment; and I can't help Wishing, tho' too late, that I had given a looser Rein to the former.

Another inconvenience was, that during the time of my Writing the two first Acts, I was entertain'd in the New Theatre, and of course prepar'd my Characters to the taste of those Actors, and they having the two most Experienc'd, I might there (without discouraging the People of this House) have expected a more Masterly Performance. In the middle of my Writing the Third Act, not liking my Station there, I return'd again
to the Theatre Royal, and was then forc'd, as far as I cou'd with nature, to confine the Business of my Persons to the Capacity of different people, and not to miss the Advantage of Mr. Doggett's Excellent Action; I prepar'd a low Character, which (tho' I dare not recommend it to the Reader) I knew from him cou'd not fail of Diverting; I have seen him Play with more success I own, but ne're saw any Man wear a truer face of Nature; and indeed the two last Acts were much better perform'd than I cou'd have propos'd in that other House; the difference is only this, had it been there I had propos'd some Scenes more of a Piece with the former Acts: But however, the performance of the whole was better than my Expectation from so thin, and I may add so uncertain a Company: For we are no more sure of the Honest Endeavours of some that are Honestly paid, than they are of Bread when they leave us: I was forc'd to Write to the Mouths of those I knew wou'd speak as well as they cou'd, and not think themselves above Instruction: Every one did their best, and I thank 'em: But however a Fort is in a very poor condition, that (in a time of General War) has but an handful of Raw young Fellows to maintain it.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: MOST Authors, when their barren Labours fail,
Still let their secret Vanity prevail;
And when they're damn'd by you, turn Wits, and rail.
'Tis not, say they, our writing well or ill,
But as the Town's i'th' mood, of damning still;
Sense, Humour, Wit, and Plot, tho' ne'er so nice,
All take the Tincture from their vain Caprice:
Their weak Digestion, and their Sickly Tast,
Nauseates this Hour, what feasted 'em the last.
Our generous Soul now's of another Mind,
He thinks you are to Mercy well inclin'd;
Show you a Beauty, and you'll soon be kind.
Nor do you care from whence the Charmer springs,
Let her soft Voice but please you while she sings.
By blest Experience this our Author knows,
Tho' from the Stage his humble Muse arose.
Your Approbation was so kindly shown,
It swell'd so high,—you swore 'twas not his own.
But tho' it were, you still thought fit to spare
The Tree, for what it might hereafter bear;
Nor damn'd the Poet for the worthless Player.
This Thought confirms him, if he fails you now,
He must his Fate to want of Merit owe,
And thinks the greatest Merit is in pleasing you.
You'll pay him well, if you approve the Feast,
And you are sure best Judges of your Tast;
If he can please—
You'll hardly starve him by a spiteful Fast.
H • hopes the best, but does your Judgments trust,
O • save, or damn his Play, he'll think you Just.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE.
div.l: YOƲR Servant Gentlemen, I am come to try
What I can do to save this Comedy:
'Twere hard shou'd a refusal be my hap,
When all I ask, is but a harmless clap.
A single Critick I'd not fear to mawle,
A Look wou'd soon make one his doom recall;
But what am I (poor thing) among you all?
Well! I'm engag'd i'th' Cause, and must go through it;
You are but Men, and therefore I'll pursue it.
I've heard there are some Ladies of the Stage,
That cock their Eyes, and dare a Criticks Rage:
Now I wou'd fain by gentle softness move you;
Ah! Jesu!—How a clap wou'd make me love you.
Beaux will be kind, I see it in their Features,
They are of such tender, melting Natures;
Look now! Were ever seen such lovely Creatures?
Heaven's! How their Smiles become 'em! O! such Graces!
I'll swear a Frown wou'd spoil their pretty Faces.
Dear Sirs be kind, and let this Play but pass,
We'll stop at nothing to deserve the Grace,
We'll hang our Stage all round with Looking-Glass.

div.head: Womans Wit: OR, THE Lady in Fashion.
ACT I.
SCENE, An Anti-Chamber.
div.stage: Enter Longville, in his Night-Gown, his Valet waiting.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Is my Sister stirring?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I saw her in the Garden above an hour a •• Sir, I • elieve she is now in her Closet.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Leave word with her Woman I am alone, and when she comes out, desire to speak with her. (Exit Laguerre.) I have observed of late, she has lost her Gaity, is much alone, and last Night, when I informed her of my Lord Lovemore's Constancy to the Ungrateful Leonora, she exrpess'd a soft Concern, that seem'd to flow from somewhat more than common Pitty. 'Twould trouble me to know she lov'd a Man, who every moment begs that Pitty from another, she wants from him; a Man whose Virtues are his Ruine, who never doing ill himself, thinks it the highest Crime to doubt the Conduct of his Mistress. I have often strove to wake him from his Lethargy, and am still resolv'd while there is hopes, never to give him o're, About this time I expect to hear from him — Who's there?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady will wait on You.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis well! has no one been to speak with me this Morning?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Only Mr. Pertwitt, Sir, the Author of the last new Play, he has left his Dedication, and says, he will Dine with you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: The Devil's in that Fellow, I find it's as Dangerous to say a Civil thing to a Dull Poet, as to an old Lady: For they are equally sure to libel your Judgment, by telling the World, you like both their Face and Fancy: When he comes give him Ten Guineas, and let me hear no more of him

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Letter for you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: A Servant from Madam Olivia.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Bid him stay. Exit Footman.
"I sha • l be in Town about Three a Clock (if my Lady Manlove can spare you) you will know where to find Olivia.
Kensington, Wednesday Morning.

If my L • dy Manlove can spare me! so, if she grudges another my Company, 'tis a sign that she has a mind to it: I'le appoint her a Meeting, and laugh at her groundless Jealously: Nay, I know she wont spare her self, when she reflects how fair a Declaration she has made me. Exit,

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Neither Devotion, Honour, Reason, Patience, or Complaint, can stop the Feaver of my distempered Thoughts: Dispair, and Love, like double Poysons, swell my Soul, yet with alternate heat and cold refuse to kill, and spightfully support a wretched Being! — Was ever Maid thus cruelly Persu'd by an unhappy Passion! To see the Man ador'd still Prostrate at my Rival's Feet, while her dissembled Coyness but inflames him more! — They talk of Men's Dispair! their Racks, and Tortures! those are Pleasures, to the Torments of a Womans secret Love! for they have still the priviledge of Speech, of soft Complaints, and dying Murmurs: But we, (hard Fate!) are ev'n Condemned by Natures Laws, to an eternal Secrecy. For Love can never break the Prison of a Virgins-Breast, while Modesty and rigid Honour are its Jaylors. O Lovemore! Why wert thou Born to wrong thy self, and ruine me?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Sister, good morrow! I have a Present for you, (gives her a Writing) —Laguerre. give this Letter to the Servant below. Exit Laguerre

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: What's here? Pray Brother, double the Favour, and without giving me the trouble of a tedious Perusal, let me know the Contents of it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis your Portion, Sister.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: My Portion?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis true, my Father left you to my care, and by his Will, gave you Ten Thousand Pound, Provided, my Consent were not wanting to your Marriage: Now, I know, there must be an uneasiness, where there is the least confinement: Therefore to free you from all doubt, and that your fear of my consent may no way check your Inclinations, I here resign my interest in your Fortune; when you can find a Man, whose Merit challenges your Esteem, or whose faithful Passion claims your Pitty, be lavish in your Gratitude, and Crown his wishes with your Bed and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: In every thing, you show your self the best and kindest Brother still: But yet, I hope, 'twill not displease you, if I return your Present: Marriage is a dangerous Journey; Love's a blind Guide, and those that follow him, too often loose their way, No! when I Love, it shall be with security, your Opinion shall first Encourage and Protect me.

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p: But Love Emilia, is a Tyrant Absolute, and never waits for sawcy Council: The time may come, when you will wish your Fortune at your own disposal! D'ee believe it impossible you shu'd ever Love?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p:
Ha! I am betray'd! his Words, his Looks have quite disarmed me! (aside.) Why Brother do you ask so strange a Question, that I shu'd ever Love!
You know I am a Woman, not cruel in my Nature, and have a Heart, which when you advise me to dispose, I shall not rather dye than part with it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: And are you sure, you have not? Did you never Love, Emilia?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: That word has ruined me! Oh never let me see the Day again! (aside.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ha! she is disorder'd! Then my fears are true: (aside.) Why are you surpris'd? I charge you with no Guilt, Emilia.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: O! I beg you ask no more. (turns away)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ha! No more! nay, then I must have all! Dear Emilia, think me not a Faithless Guardian, that wou'd take a base advantage of thy Love: Look on me as I am thy careful Brother, that thinks his Life no longer useful, than in serving thee: Nay, ev'n in thy Love I'll serve thee, and hope 'tis in my power too: Come, lay aside thy Fears, and reason calmly with me.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Reason with you! Why do you wish me plung'd in Deeper Misery? For Reason ever sets a wild Dispair before me.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Do not indulge these Melancholy Thoughts; name me the Man, that thus disturbs thee?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Then indeed, you will pitty me! — I owe my weakness to your nearest Friend.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I think, my Lord Lov • more is my nearest!

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Indeed, he b • st deserves that Happiness.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: But such a Friend will never make my Sister wretched

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Al •• ! His Love, which su • e out weighs his Friendship, aims • very hour to me 〈◊〉 anothe • happy.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
H ••
•• ve, Emil • a, is grounded on your Rival's Virtue, and judge your self, how wea •• s that Foundation.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I grant she is inconstant, loose, and dangerous, as the Sand; yet, his Eye, the false Optick of his Love, presents her as a fixt unshaken Rock whereon he vows to build his Happiness.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: But I shall shortly turn the Friendly end o'th' Tube, and draw her failings nearer to his view: Of which this very day, I have engag'd to give him a clear convincing Prospect.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Which way; I beg you let me know; for 'twere a second Happiness not to see him wretched.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thus it is — In a Dispute yesterday with my Lord, concerning Leonora, I urg'd his weakness home, and laid her falshood clear before him. At length, my Friendly Arguments brought him to this Conclusion. About an hour hence by his free Consent, I am to visit her, and have leave to feign my self her Lover, and urge my Passion with all the seeming tenderness that Friendship can inspire, and if my Art can drag from her, the least acknowledgement of Love for me: Or but an ungenerous Contempt of his unwearied Constancy, he vows, his deep Resentment shou'd for ever tear her from his Heart.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: It has a Face, indeed; but how will my Lord be witness of her Falshood.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I have already Brib'd her Servant, who is to place him where, unseen, he shall both hear, and see it all.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: There's Danger in the Attempt: Be wary Brother, for shou'd her artful Eyes ensnare you too, then I were doubly wretched.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nourish no such Fear, Emilia, I have a treble Guard upon my Heart, the baseness of her Soul, my own Honour, and a Sisters Peace.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: Sir, my Lord Lovemore!

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Farewel! I'll study to deserve your Care: I dare not stay; excuse me, lest my Guilt betray me.
Brother, your Servant, I'll leave you to your Business.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: We have none of that Consequence, Madam, to be preferr'd to your Company.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: My Lord! I beg you will excuse me: I am in haste, 'tis Chappel-time.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: 'Twere a Sacriledge unpardonable, Madam, to hinder your Devotion, a Universal Blessing to the World.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: My Lord, your Servant. Exit Emilia.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Your Sister, Charles, is a very agreeable Woman; why don't you look out a Match for her, you are her Guardian.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I have her Fortune to dispose of, my Lord: But not her Inclination, when she has chosen, I am ready to pay down the Mony.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Her Mony may raise many a false pretended Passion, and young Women seldom want a little hardned Vanity to stamp it into Currant Love.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I hope, my Lord, in a little time to give you a very fair Proof of her Judgment.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Prithee, let me understand you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis yet an Infant secret, in a Day or two it may speak plainer; in the mean time, my Lord, how stands your Resolution towards my Design upon Leonora?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Faith, Charles, I have yet some scruples, but as they rise, my Confidence in thy Friendship still removes 'em: What time do you propose to visit her? (Looking on his Watch)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Now this Morning.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: You will be too late 'tis within half an hour of Twelve.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Time enough! We shall find her at her Toilet till two, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: That's scarce time enough to set your Peruke: For I suppose you design to Comb her into Compliance. A First Rate Beaux at least? Do you consider how much time is requir'd in the making such an Animal?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Half an hour does it as well as half a score, Man.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: You wou'd be of another Opinion, if you were at my Lord Tiffle-Tops Levee.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: No, no! 'Tis not that his Lordship has occasion to employ half the the Morning at his Glass: But the soft Rogue can't part with his own Dear Image under six hours Admiration: For a powder'd Wig is as soon put on, as an Uncomb'd one: 'Tis not a fine Coat, but Affectation that makes a Fop: and that you know is a kind of Surtout, a Man may slip it over his Cloaths.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Then you think a little Affectation will certainly Recommend you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Take the Boxes round upon the full third Day of a Favour'd Poet, you'll scarce find three Beauties will allow you a Gentleman without it: I never
knew your fine set up Woman of Quality, that did not spend three parts of her Life in studying the Art of Je-ne-scais-Quoyity!

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: Well, I yet hope you are mistaken in Leonora: What you call Affectation, to me has always been the Height of Breeding, a Modest Freedom, an Agreeable Gayity, and an Invincible Coldness.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I am sorry my Lord your Disease is so desperate, that nothing but the Exposing her can Cure you: For I own 'tis much against my Nature to Triumph o're a Womans Weakness: But if Women are Weak, who shall Trust 'em? And if I see my Friend in Danger, shall not I show the Snare prepar'd for him?

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: 'Twas thus I had Excus'd you to my self before: But do you believe her false through Weakness, or Design?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: O she wants no Wit, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: How then do you propose to win her by an affected Passion, when my Sincerity cannot move her?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Your Sincerity never will my Lord: She is light by Nature, hates a Man that Preaches Virtue by Example, and shows the bareness of her Principles by the firmness of his own; She loves a Wretch that Joyns with her in Vanity, your Gay Unthinking Spark, by the Comparison of whose Nonsense she admires her own Wit: Beside, I have some Reason to believe she likes me.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: What Reason?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: By her publickly declaring an Aversion to me.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: She will not deny it to your Face I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady Manlove is in a Chair below, and desires to know if you have any Company with you?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Though I am loath to trust my Person with her, I wou'd be civil to the Mother of your Mistress, my Lord: Desire her Ladyship to walk up, and tell her I am alone: It won't be amiss first to expose the Mothers Character▪ (aside) This is the third Visit I have had from her this week, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Lov.
sp.p: How came you so intimate?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: One day unfortunately commending the fulness of her Eye, or so, she cou'd not rest till she had taken me aside to ask me, if my Designs were Honourable? And ever since she is eternally labouring to convince me, that she has no real Aversion to Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: You see what 'tis to be Complaisant, Charles.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If you step into that Closet my Lord, perhaps you may over-hear something that will surprize you; however, your time won't be lost, there lyes a Milton upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: You'll oblige me.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Here she comes! away my Lord. [Ld Lov. goes into the Closet.]

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Madam! Your most humble Servant, this is an unexpected Favour.

sp.speaker: L Ma.
sp.p:
Why a Favour Sir! D'ee think I'll ever grant a Favour to any Man. I'll swear we Women of Quality had need live lock'd up in a Closet, if we wou'd avoid Scandal. Can't one pay an harmeless Visit, but you must immediately
conclude one designs you a Favour, I vow to Gad I came with a design to b • , a Favour o • you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis a Favour Madam, that you will make use on me:

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Use you? Really Sir, I don't understand you? What do you mean? — But come! — To let you see I dare relye upon my own Conduct,— Come Sir, I will venture to sit down by you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Oh! Mad • m, you honour me.
•• ey sit.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: Well! Mr. Longville, you little think what a secret Busi ••• s I have to Communicate to you! I hope we are private! Pray let us be private, and I will lay it open to you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: — (to Laguerre) Wait without! — Now! M • dam!

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: You must know Sir, that I came to advise with you about!—about a— I'll swear Mr. Longville, you look mighty well to day!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: — That might be said more justly of your Ladyship, Madam!

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: O Lord! I! Oh! Jesu! I am all in a Flame! such a Colour! Prithee do but feel my pulse a little! — So if I can but get into Discourse with him, I may save my Business for another Visit to Morrow. aside.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: They are very high indeed Mad • m; but you look the better for it.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Is't possible! well! Mr. Longville, I am inclin'd in real Charity, to encourage all your Offers, if it were only to keep you from ill Women; for I know there are some so ravenous of you, that they follow you to your Chamber in a Morning, and have the Confidence to force themselves upon you; Now Dear sweet Mr. Longville, don't encourage these confident Creatures: Let me beg it of you for your own sake.— pressing his hand.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: So! I fi • d no Woman sees an ugly Face in her own Glass. aside.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: I'll swear I cou'd find in my Heart to visit you every Morning, meerly to prevent those wicked Creatures having their ends of you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That were too great a trouble! No! Madam I have an admirable way to avoid 'em: Shall I show you how I wou'd use such a Woman? I ask your Pardon, Madam, but supposing you were such a one!

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Oh! foh! I hate to act an odious Part: holding his hand.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why, you can't miss it, Madam, you need but sit as you do! — Now Madam, squ • eze my hand a little.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: O! Jesu! I cou'd not do it for the Universe! lets it go suddenly.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Then I must suppose you had done it, Madam, upon which I flatly, tell her that—

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Pish (Rises) Lord! What care I what you tell her: If you will let me tell you my Business, say so!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: (Walking after her.) I say, Madam, I tell her, that my Inclinations lye elsewhere; that she flings away her time; that her Fondness is more disagreeable than her Person; that I wonder at her impudence in taking Civility for Love: That she is ugly without Exception, Coy without Coldness, in Love without Hope, Nice without Offers, Wanton without Youth, Kind without Courtship, and Craving without Conscience.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Well! Well! have you done yet? — Pish!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That her keeping Company is Design, that her Designs are Man, that her Man is Every body; that Nobody is hers; that her Charms are quite exhausted, and Time writes upon her Fore-head,—Pray Remember the Poor!

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Prithee! What a Humour's this?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That her Modesty is more painted than her Face, and both so much, that no Man can see e • ther of them.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Mr. Longville!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That her Company is worse then Sickness; and that I had as lieve be visited by the Small Pox.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Pish! Will you never ha' done?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That in short she is so detestable, that ev'n the Pleasure of Revenge cou'd not raise me to give her a Clap. The Devil's in't if this won't undeceive her! aside.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: I don't understand him! Sure, he can't mean all this to me! I find I must tell him my Business to put him out of this Humour! Prithee, Mr. Longville sit down a little, I want some of your Advice Man; Lord! you have quite tir'd your self!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Now, Madam, your Commands! they sit.

sp.speaker: L Man.
sp.p: I suppose Sir you are not ignorant of my Lord Lovemores Passion for my Daughter: Now Sir he being your particular Friend, and I having a particular Inclination to serve any one that is your Friend, Mr. Longville, I have resolv'd to make my Daughter Marry my Lord out of Hand; and have contriv'd a way to make her sole Heiress of my Husbands Estate.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: This is obliging, Madam; But how can it be while you have a Son living?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Ah! don't call him my Son Mr. Longville, Education can't Polish him! he is of such a slovenly Nature, he is fit for nothing but a Clergyman: Now you must know all my Family being Catholicks, I have a Mind to make a Priest of him, and have accordingly provided him a Governour to go with him to St. Omers: Then Sir I being his Guardian, and having the Estate all in my own Hands —

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Will take care it shall never come to his. (aside.) But why a Priest, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: To prevent his Marrying Man, and then his Estate comes of Course to my Daughter, and so to my Lord, and his Heirs.— Beside, one is not sure of his getting safe to St. Omers!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Inhumane Devil! A Priest! Death! She is going to Ship him to Barbadoes! (aside.) Well Madam! Wherein can I be serviceable to you?

sp.speaker: L. Ma
sp.p: You! Why you can—you can— Lord! Can you do one no Kindness d'ye think? Let me see!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Not the Kindness you think on; Death! How she's puzzled for a Pretence for her Visit? aside.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Pish! — O Gad! I had like to have forgot! you must know my Business hither was to get you to—to—to a! O! to perswade the Boy to go.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: So! Now she has found it. aside.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Now Dear Mr. Longville, (pressing his Hand) Let me beg of you to use all means possible to perswade him; for I know the Boy will do any thing at your bidding.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Well Madam, I'll use my Interest to serve you—in your kind. aside.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Wil • you give me your Word, and Honour?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Both, to have my hand agen. aside.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Nay! but you must give me your hand upon't!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why you have it, you have it, Madam!

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Pshah! but you don't give it me heartily!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Humh! She will have a squeeze, I find. (aside.) There Madam, 'tis heartily.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: Sir, Young Mr. Rakish desires to speak with you, immediately.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: At last I am deliver'd. (aside.)—Bid him walk up.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: O! Jesu! Mr. Longville! I wou'd not be seen for the Universe.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: O! you need not, Madam, here's a back way.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Well! but my Dear Charles, when shall I see you about this Business?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: In a quarter of an hour, Madam, at your own House: I have some private Business with your Daughter: When I have dispatch'd it, I am at your Service. (Pressing her to go.)

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Well! I have the prettiest Closet to show you Mr. Longville! — I'll swear I have no mind to leave you yet: Can't I step in there, till he is gone, a little? (offering towards the Closet)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: The Devil! (aside.) Madam, upon my Honour, I will but Dress and wait upon you. Here he comes! away Madam!

sp.speaker: L. Man
sp.p: Well! Adieu, my Dear, dear, dear Creature! Ex. L. Man.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Come my Lord now I'll release you.
Did you hear us?

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: Yes, and am amaz'd! Prithee! What does she mean by St. Omers, and her Son, it can't be real?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Too sure my Lord, I have heard of it before.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: I am sorry she shou'd make me her Pretence for so base an Action! How shall we prevent it?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That I will undertake: But first I will let you see your Mistress has a Hand in't. (aside.) Laguerre! My Cloaths!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: How now Jack! What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: O! Charles I am undone, if you don't stand by me! my Father's just at my Heels—my Lord your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: Poor Jack! What hast thou done to him now Man!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Done my Lord? Pox take him: only nothing but a piece of Justice; for the old Rogue had the Conscience last Night to offer to Cheat me of Fifty Pound, tho' he knew 'twas all I had in the World, and in return, I very fairly nick'd him of Five Hundred upon the square.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: Prithee how was it?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Why you must know, my Lord, he wou'd ha' put the Doctor upon me, and Communicated his Design to Ned Friendly, who immediately told me of it; upon which (unknown to him) I flung away the Doctor, and clapt into the Box a Pair of True Mathematicks: Fortune was on my side, and in less then two Hours I fairly nickt him of Five Hundred Pound.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: Well! and what wou'd the old Gentleman have?

sp.speaker: Y. R.
sp.p: When the Business was over, Ned laught at him, and told him what I had done; upon which he whip'd out his Sword, and in a great Passion swore, if I did not refund the Money, he wou'd disenherit me before to Morrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: What Answer did you make him?

sp.speaker: Y. R.
sp.p: Why faith, e'vn took no notice of him: but very fairly slunk away to his Goldsmith, and to hasten his paying the Money, politickly told him, I had just killed a Man: Egad the inhumane Son of a Whore took hold of the Opportunity, and made me pay Fifteen p • r Cent. for Expedition.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: The rest you secur'd in Specie, I suppose!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Ay! ay! here it is, all in Gold, my Boy! Prithee, Dear Charles, secure it for me; as for my Life, which I know he will pursue, I'll venture to defend that my self.

div.stage: Enter a Footman to young Rakish.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sir, your Father's just coming up! one of the Servants ignorantly told him you were in the House, and he immediately drew his Sword, and has search'd every Room below for you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Ounds! the Money! the Money, Charles!

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p: There! into that Closet; and take the Key on the inside, till we have appeas'd him. Young Rakish goes into the C • o • et. Laguerre, lock up this. Gives him the Money.

div.stage: Enter Major Rakish with his Sword drawn, he searches the Room.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Where is this Rogue! This Villain! This sharping Dog?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why how now Major! What in a Passion Man?

sp.speaker: Lon. & Ld. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! What's the matter Major? ha! ha! he!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: No! no! nothing but Murder, nothing but Murder shall satisfie me.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: What is it you look for Major?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Only a High-way-man, my Lord, was not he here with you just now?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: A High-way-man with us Sir!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: One that is in the Road to the High-way; do you know Jack Rakish, my Lord!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I knew him for a very honest fellow Sir.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: — Why I got him— That very Dog did I get.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I don't question that Sir.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: But you wou'd Sir, if you knew how he has serv'd me—Nothing vexes me, but that I can't swear a Robbery against the Dog; for then a Man might have had some hopes of the forty Pound upon his Conviction.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Fye! Major, you shou'd give him a better Allowance, that his Necessity might not force him to such Extremity!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Allowance! a Dog! has not Nature given him a strong Back? let him live by that; let him turn Beau, and live upon tick; let him lye with his Laundress, get in with his Semstress, help his Taylor to Custom, Dine with me, Bilk his Lodging,—and now and then sharp a Play in the side Box.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: This I know he is very often forc'd to do: But Faith. Major, it don't answer the Character of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: A Gentleman! O • nds! don't I see fifty there every day, that have no Income but their Wits, and yet have very good Cloaths upon their Backs!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: And carry all they have upon their Backs! Come, come, you must allow better Man.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Allow him! What a Pox! Don't I allow to D • ink, and Whore, and Fight, and Roar where he pleases, provided he keeps me Company—the Devil a stroke else—I co'd—I will have my share, while I live old Boy— No! no! Old Jack must come in for a bit of Wickedness by the By, or so—must take Care of old Jack!—old Jack must be taken care of—Allow him Quotha'! What a Pox! must the silly Dog needs be a Buble? Can't he take the Pleasure of Lewdness without the Folly of paying for't? Ods bu'd I sometimes break half a dozen Commandments in a day, and it ne'er costs me a Farthing.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lov.
sp.p: Say you so, Major? Faith I wou'd advise you to publish your Receipt, it may Reform most of our young Fellows about Town.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: How do you mean Reform! ha! Old Politick of the World?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Why look ye! if we cou'd once lessen the Charge of Lewdness, you long-liv'd niggardly Fathers wou'd certainly take it up; and Vice wou'd look so nauseous in Sixty odd, that one, and twenty wou'd grow asham'd on't.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: But, Sir, my Son is not ash • m'd o' his Vice, and I'd have you to know I am a— a very lew'd old Fellow! But I don't pay for't, I don't pay for't, like a raw Inns of Court Beau, that is just set up for Iniquity.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Prithee, Major, how do you Manage your Pleasures, that you say they cost you nothing?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: I'll tell you, my Lord, I'll tell you how I spent the day before Yesterday: I got up, and Din'd with Sir Bartholomew Bumper, Drank my two Bottles and half with him by five a Clock—Then call'd in at the Play (Impudence my Ticket) pick'd up a Parson's Wife, gave her the Remains of an old Clap, and so pawn'd her at Phillip's for three pints of Spirit of Clary:— After this I call'd in at the Rose, found three or four young strong Dogs damnable Hungry, sent a Porter for a slice of Sir Bartholomew's Brawn, drank my two Bottles more, call'd for a Bill, Brawn paid old Jacks Club, old Jack reels into a Coach, Bilks him, slips to Bed, wakes in five hours with a steddy Hand, and no aking Head, by the Lord Harry.

sp.speaker: L. Love.
sp.p: Well said, Major!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: There's management for you! Why cou'd not my Dog-Rogue of a Son do this? He wants a thousand Pound with a Pox to him! Odsbu'd I lose time, I must ferret the Dog— Hey! where abouts a • e you? Soho! Jayl bird! looks about.

sp.speaker: Y. R.
sp.p: (Peeping.) Igad I had as good show my self, while I have a Friend or two to stand by me. He steals behind the Major, and walks softly after him.

sp.speaker: Lon. & L. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Unconscionable Rogue, a thousand Pound at one Clap! aside.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why you that spend no Money Major, methinks shou'd have no occasion for it: But was it a full thousand Pound, say you?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Umh! not a full thousand Pound: Look ye I won't lye neither: But may I never more hear the Dear Glugg, Glugg of a full Flask, if it was not above eight hundred.

sp.speaker: Y. R.
sp.p: That's a Lye! Claps him on the back.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: O Dog! Villain! Rogue! Sirrah, How dare you look me in the Face? Draw! Draw! Rascal! They hold him.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Yes Sir! Draws, and stands on his Guard.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: What you will Murder me in cool Blood! will you Dog!

sp.speaker: Y. R.
sp.p: Yes Sir! I believe I shall: For I don't find my self angry yet.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Why Sirrah! Newgate! am not I your Father, ha!

sp.speaker: Y. R.
sp.p: Look you Sir! if you are my Father, I draw in Obedience to your Commands; if not, upon my Enemy—stand off.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Now have not I one word to say to him— This Impudence melts my very Soul—There's a Look! There's a Forehead! There's Brass for you! The Rogue wou'd make an admirable Player in the old House; Od b'ud! I have more mind to kiss him, then to be angry by half— Well! Sirrah! What have you to say for your self?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Nay, first old Gentleman! Lets hear what you have to say against me?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Have you not Bit me, my Dear Son?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Have you not starv'd me my Dear Dad?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Have not I lov'd you— you yound Dog?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Have not I return'd it, old Hock!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Have you return'd it— Sawce!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Yes Sir! By this generous Confidence in your Love, in taking the freedom to win your Five Hundred Pound, well knowing that so Trivial Summ cou'd not hurt me in your Favour.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Umh! Here's a Rogue!—Well! and so! you think I will forgive you!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Dam mee! Sir, who dares say to the contrary?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Ah! the Rogue has me now! That Look has quite dissolv'd me; Odsb'ud I can no more ressist him, than a Patenteè can a pretty Wench, when she demands an unconscionable Sallery in the Play-house. Well! I must forgive you then! humh!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: I knew you wou'd, or else I had ne'er nick'd you.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Why look you Sir, then ev'n set your Heart at rest: For before these Gentlemen, I solemnly declare that—that— I do forgive you, upon Condition.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: What Condition?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Uumh! That I have my Money agen!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: The Devil!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, you shall leave the Conditions to me; my Lord and I have just an hours Business together; I'll bring the Money with me to Lockets. between one and two; where we'll Dine, and set all to rights agen!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Say no more my little Charles, I'll go before, and bespeak Dinner! But hark you, had not you as good let me take the Money along with me?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: I barr that old Gentleman! no! no! Possession is eleven Points in the Law!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: A rare Look that! — it's a good Look! — the Dog has a good Look!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Come, Old Jack! let's you and I take a whet of Racy Canary before they come—My Lord, your Humble Servant; by Charles.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Hold! hold! my little Jacky, not too fast—Cede Majoribus.

div.stage: (Pulls Young Rakish back, and goes out before him.)

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: A Pleasant Couple these!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ay, and only Pleasant, when they are Coupled.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Right! they are like the two Parts of a Drunken Song, very indiff • rent Musick, unless you hear 'em both together.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: But now and then they may be endur'd the better to relish the Harmony of a Refin'd Conversation. Come, my Lord, now for Leonora.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: You remember the Conditions, if you fail in your Attempt, you are never to speak against he • more.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Agreed: if I succeed, the consequence will reward me.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: You see Charles how fond I am of being still your Friend, that I dare hazard all my Happiness in Leonora, meerly to satisfie your Jealousie, not my own.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You wou'd be Jealous too my Lord, were you less a Lover, and I more favourable; were I less your Friend: 'Tis my Care of you that makes me Jealous; and the Generosity of your Love, that will not let you doubt your Leonora.

q.l: When Beauty gives the Lover warm desire,
Awakes his Reason, and uns • als his Eyes. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: ACT. II.
SCENE, Lady Manloves House.
div.stage: Leonora at her Toilet, her Woman D • essing her.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Let's see this Mornings Letters.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: There are only these half Dozen Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No more! Barbarity! This 'tis to go to Hyde-Park upon a Windy Day, when a well Dress'd Gentleman can't stir abroad: The Beaus were • orc't to take shelter in the Play-House I suppose: I was a Fool, I did not go thither, I might have made ten times the Havock in the side Boxes.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Your Ladyship's being out of Humour with the Exchange Woman, for Shaping your Ruffles so Odiously, I am afraid made you a little too reserv'd Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Prithee! Was there a Fop in the whole Ring, that had not a side Glass from me! Nay, ev'n that Insensible Wretch Longville, watcht the Circulation of my Chariot with an unusual Assiduity. The Humility of his Bow has given me some hopes of Revenging the Affront he put upon me last Week.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O Dear, Madam! I always took him for a well Bred Gentleman! Cou'd he Affront your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O in the grossest manner! He sate two whole Hours alone with me in my Dressing Room, and was as far from making me any offers of Love or Gall antry, as if I had been his Mother.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Perhaps your Ladyship gave him no Encourag • ment Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Quite contrary! I Languisht in my Glass, laid my Neck bare, Smil'd on him, talkt of Love, made him draw on my Gloves, tye on my Necklace; nay, take my Dormouse out of my very Bosom: But all in vain, he did it with all the coldness of a Brother, no more mov'd than if he had been my Husband. O he Tortur'd me so I could not bear him!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I am affraid Madam, by this Uneasiness your Ladyship likes him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No Fool! But 'twere an uneasiness not to have him like me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You know Madam, he's Engag'd to Olivia, and I am confident can have no good meaning any where else.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: His meaning cou'd do me no Prejudice; let him be once my Lover, I'll soon lead him into the Road of Honour.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I suppose Madam, your Ladyship wou'd not have him Travel as far as Marriage.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Marriage! No, no! This Face is not to be flung away upon a Husband yet: I Love as your great Generals Fight, not for Peace, but Glory: Marriage is a m • er Cessation of Arms: When I can hold out no longer I am secure of an Honourable Retreat in my Lord Lovemore: The Reputation of his Sense, and his six Years Constancy, sufficiently satisfies the World, that I am not at a loss for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Your Ladyship has a very working Brain Madam, you were Born to Conquer.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And Bred so too! I began my little Wars of Love before Th • rteen, heav'd my Breasts at Twelve, and entertain'd my Train of Dangling Beaux with all the Affected Coldness of One and Twenty: Nay, ev'n then had a Soul so sensible of Glory, I Fought my three Duels a Week, Kill'd now and then my Man, and as one fell, was still designing on another.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: For Heavens sake, Madam, Did your Ladyship use to Fight Duels,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Stupid Creature! 'Twas Leonora Fought: Her Eyes inflam'd the Combat, she drew the Sword secure of Conquest; for both the Victor, and the Victim were Leonora's still.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Madam, my Lady Manlove.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Good morrow Child, What not Dress'd yet?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I am just Ready, Madam, has your Ladyship been Abroad?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Ay, I have been with Father Benodic about your Brother Joh • ny. He will be here this Afternoon: And just as I had left him, whom shou'd I meet coming out of his Lodgings but Mr. Longville. — He s • ys, he has some Private Business with you, Child: He will be here in a moment: Prithee make what haste you can with him, that I may talk with him further about your Brothers Journey. — I long to have the Dear Creature in Private again. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'll observe you, Madam, I will soon Dispatch him.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Prithee do Child, in the mean time I'll go a • d prepare your Brother. (Exit L Man.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
Some Private Business with me! — Nay then. — (she Prides, and se • s her self in her Glass.) Oh Jesu! This is a frightful Head! Here Triffle! Fetch me that with the Blew Knts. (Takes off her Commode.) — D'ye hear! my Crimson Gown and Petticoat. — O! I can't contain my self! Methinks I see
him at my Feet! Dispairing! Dying! Breathing out his last Complaint of Love! — Why don't you stir you senseless Creature! Hold! hold! Stay a little! Lay down the Head! Go you and wait below, to give me notice of his coming. And d'ye hear, send Lettice to Dress me in the next Room, here he may Surprize me. — Go! go! Make haste Lump! For my Revenge is more Impatient than another's Love. (She runs off bare-headed, her Gown loose about her, &c.) Exit Triffle at the other Door: And then—

div.stage: Enter Lettice, who in haste takes up the Things, and follows Leonora; after which, Enter Triffle, with Lord Lovemore, and Longville.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Where's your Lady?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Hearing you were to be here, Sir, she went immediately into the next Room to change her Dress.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: D'ye hear that, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Is her Decency a Fault?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Her Design is.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Prithee no more, I am Impatient till thou hast prov'd thy self a Mad-man. — Come! Where's my Post?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Here my Lord, in this Avenue. — There's a Door upon your Right Hand, that leads you to the Back Stairs.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: When I pull out my Handkercher, let that be your Cue to go round, and come in at this Door, as tho' you knew nothing of what had past.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I shall observe you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Be sure! Whatever you hear, don't let your Resentment Discover you before your time: For shou'd she find you overheard her, she will certainly face you down, she knew of your being there, and that she receiv'd me kindly only to Revenge your Affronting Jealousie.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Humh! (Smilling.) you are mighty Cautious — I give you my Honour to observe your Directions.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Follow Triffle, my Lord, [She places L. Lovemore unseen.] Here, Child, there's another Purse for thy good Service: Let your Lady know I am here. — [Exit Triffle.] — So! Now for a little Scandalous Railery upon your Top-Beauties of Quality to Recommend my Judgment in her: Let me see! Which will be my best way to deliver my Passion? — Pox I need not study set Speeches: For she has so much of the Coquet in her, that you can no more fall from the Discourse of Love in her Company, than you can be Raised to Act it in her Mothers: My Design has hitherto been so Prosperous, I can hardly think Success will fail me now. — Beside the Liberty of my Friend draws the Curtain to my Sisters Hopes. — But, see! She is here!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Lord! — Mr. Longville! What Accident has Blest us with your good Company? For unless some extraordinary Business brings you, you are no more to be seen, than a Lawyer in Term-time.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: O! Madam! My Life's an eternal Term, Love's my Cause, and you are my Judge.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Poor Wretch! I have him now! (Aside.) I shall be glad to be of Counsel for you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: To tell you the Truth, Madam, 'twas a little of your Advice I now came for: For my Cause is coming on this very Moment: Gad take me it has cost me the Lord nows what to Qualifie me for the Bar of Love: I am resolved now to make my Appearance! Have you perceived no Alteration in me, Madam, these two Days?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'll swear, I think I have! Won't you sit, Mr. Longville.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Hey! who's there?
Bid the Coach-man go home and—let five of my Men wait me at Chaves's, you only below, I am in Private. — Hey! let 'em all stay, I'd have the World know where I pay my Devoir. (Bows.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well, I swear, Mr. Longville, nothing speaks a Gentleman more than his Equipage, the whole Ring Yesterday took notice of your Chariot. Ah! Jesu! Such a lolling easie Air! Then the Six clean Creatures that Drew it had their Mains and Tails so finely Curl'd and Powder'd, that their very motion gave a new born sweetness to the Ev'ning.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Do you know, Madam, that the great Du • ch Beau, Minheer Van Powderback offer'd me a Hundred Guineas for a Brace of their Tails, to make him a Peruke.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Let me Dye! But you are a second Phaeton! This Equipage and Chariot, were enough to set the whole Beau Mond on Fire! Jesu! 'tis not Ten Days ago, since you were the strangest Rough Creature, always in a Plain Coat: But two Horses to your Coach, a single Footman behind it, and scarce Powder enough in your Perriwig to whiten the inside of it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ha! ha! Gad take me, Madam, your Ladiship has hit me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But Jesu! who is this Powerful Beauty, that has wrought this Wonderous Alteration?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Your Ladiship is very intimate with her: Can't you Guess her Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O Sir! 'twere hard to do that among so many Beauties, as this Town affords.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Beauties! ha! ha! Pray Madam, do me the Favour to name one of those things y • u call Beauties? That a Gentleman can bear the Thoughts on?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O! Fie! Mr. Longville! there's a World of 'em! What do you think of my Lady Slattern Pinchit? She is an Heiress, understands the Management of a Family to a Miracle, and I'vow has really a great deal of Wit.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! my Lady Slattern Pinchit! I must confess she has Two Thousand Pound a Year to Recommend her Nauseous Houswifry, which is enough to turn ones Stomach! Pray, Madam, let me give you an account of a Visit I made her, at her Lodgings at the Bath last Summer.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O Filthy Irish Creature, the very Apprehension of it gives me the Vapours: For Heav'ns sake no more!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nay Gad, Madam, it's worth your Hearing: You must know I had a mind to surprize her: When I was got up Stairs I Bolted into her B • d-Chamber, where I found my Prudent Lady, and her Couzen, Bare-headed at Dinner—upon the Remains of a Cold Leg of Lamb, and Cucumbers!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O! my Soul!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: The sight of me drove them immediately into the Closet, from whence they cu s'd, and storm'd at me through the Key-hole, worse than if I had caught them Naked: In the mean time I took a view of her Chamber, and found under her Chair half a Bottle of Bristol-milk, upon the seat of it lay her Garters, and a Pair of Green Worsted Stockings, and upon the Back of it hung a Daub'd Diaper Napkin above an Inch thick of Pomatum.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Insuppo • table!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Upon her Toilet lay the Overplus of her Complexion, in the Print of three Re • Fingers upon the corner of a Callico Nightrail.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O! I shall Die!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Upon the Chest of Drawers lay a Pair of old Slippers, with a Dirty Suit of N ght cloaths, a Pound of Butter, and a Raw Phillet of Veal wrapt in the Tayl of her Bathing Smock.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
A • !
• queling out.
I'gad, Madam, if you are no better at Pointing me out a Conquest, I shall ev'n be forc'd to attack your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: O Jesu! I'll name all the Town first! Not but I believe I may stop at Fine Mrs. Cour • ly, she that my Lord Cou'd-n' • -brook fought about.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I'll commend her to see how she will take it. [Aside.] She is very Handsome, Madam, and all the World allows her a Woman of Extraordinary Breeding!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do they so Sir! Nay I'll swear I can't blame you, really she is very much a Gentlewoman! so Easie! so Free! so agreeable and good Humour'd! I vow to Gad my Lady Censure, and I were ready to fall out about her, she says she is the most Affected Piece, that ever cross'd the Drawing-Room, one of her sideling Curt'sys turns her Stomack.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why Faith, Madam, as my Lady says, now and then she does screw her self confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O the most intollerable, vain Fantastick Creature breathing; the Duce take me Mr. Longville, if she had • ot the confidence to report that Sir John Lovewell was kill'd upon her account?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ridiculous! all the World knows, Madam, he fell a Victim to your Eyes! S' Death! how loth she is to lose the Glory of a Man's Murther! Aside.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: (Behind.) What does he Fool with me? Is this the worst of her he can show me? Women are all censorious: But now it may be complaisance to him, that makes her so: I will have patience; for shu'd I interrupt him, there wu'd be no end of his idle Jealousies.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Still wide, Madam, the Lady I mean is one whose sense, and Beauty, ev'n envious Wit can find no fault in.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Jesu! Mr. Longville, this is a Complement to the whole Sex to believe there can be such a Woman: I'll swear I wou'd give the World to know her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Will you hear me, Madam, if I name her? have I your word, it shall not ma • e you leave the Room.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Prith • e, why shu'd you think that? You don't intend to conjure with her N • me, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: No, Madam, I only dread the Magick of her Eyes!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: • esu! what makes you so Grave?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Twere an Insolence unpardonable, Madam, to see a Malefactor Merry at the Bar.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: To take my Trial, Madam, for the crime of Love; Therefore I claim the Promise of your Counsel; and beg to know if it were possible for a Lover to make his Passion grateful to you, in what manner wu'd you most willingly receive it? Deliver'd with a gay Assurance between Jest and Earnest, or with a Rough Downright Bluntness; or else with all the Passionate Submissive Vows, that Love and Truth cou'd teach him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Your own Reason will resolve you. A real Passion can't be Jested with, and your Rough Lover is a Brute: No! I own 'tis Tenderness, and sost Complaint, a Dying look, Heart-breaking sighs, and Tears alone cou'd move my nature to a Relenting Pity.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: So! now she has instructed me! I shall go on with a good Assurance! [Aside.] You cou'd not sure despise a Lover so complaining. (Sighs.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nature it self abhors so Barbarous a Thought.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Then give me leave to kneel before you.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! This is to the purpose. (Behind.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The Fool's undone! Ruin'd past Redemption! Jesu! Prithee rise!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Not tell you assure me, that you believe me serious.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well!—a—Rise! I dare do that, while you are sitting. (They sit.)

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Confusion! she rejects him not. (Behind.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'll vow you surprize me, Mr. Longville! I never dream't of love from you!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: My Lord Lovemore, Madam, being long my Friend before he was my Rival, oblig'd me to conceal my Passion from the world, and you: Nay so sacred was my Friendship, that ev'n opportunity, which Madam, our Intimacy has often given me, cou'd not hitherto betray me to a guilty Glance.—But now the violence of my love forces me to confess my Soul, to sacrifice that Friend, and curse him by the name of Rival: Therefore in spite of Bonds, (Kneeling.) to you I offer up my heart, and shou'd his Interposing Vows but rob me of a smile of yours, his life's the Sacrifice I'll make to your Mistaken Charity.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Fy! Mr. Longville, this to me! Lord! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What the Devil shall I say now? (Aside)

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: So tame at the Discovery! (Behind.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: In Pity, Madam, think me real, and if you have already blest him with the Rich Treasure of your conquer'd Heart, be at least so generously cruel to confirm the truth of it to a miserable despairing Wretch, and from this moment my Passion shall be dumb, and trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! I am Tortur'd with my Fears. (Behind.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: (aside.) Well is there any Rapture like the glory of a Prostrate Lover? Now to raise his Giddy Hopes, while like his shadow I still fly before him, seem always near, yet never to be o're taken.—Pray rise!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Never while my Rival stands before me in your Favour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Jesu! sure you are not in Earnest.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Your coldness, Madam, tells me indeed you wou'd not have me so.— Nay then my Rival has your Heart, and you in Generous Pity to my Love, wou'd fain conceal it— (Rises.)—No Madam, there's no • but this to chose, that since I can't be yours to be no more.—Madam! Farewell. (Ʋnbuttens himself.)
May you be happy in my Rival's Love.—His life I wou'd not, dare not touch because 'tis dear to you—But th •• I sacrifice my own. (Offering to Draw.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ah! for Heavens sake what do you mean? (Holds Him.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: To trouble you no more. (Strugling.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Lord! I hope you won't offer any mischief! hear me but speak!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You have said too much already: Pray let me die in quiet. S'Death will she hinder me, or no? (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O dear Mr. Longville don't talk of dying! Jesu! if he shu'd kill himself here he wou d all spoil my Floor: Beside I shall loose the Pleasure of fooling him. [aside] —Pray give me your Sword!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Madam, Despair, and life are Insupportable.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hold! O hold!— You have touch'd my soul so tenderly, that with a thousand Burning Blushes I must intreat you live, if Hope can save you: O! never let the fear of any Rival shock your Hopes, and least my Lord Lovemore, his Person, and his Grave Behaviour were ever my Aversion, had not my Mothers Commands forbad me I had long ago inform'd him so.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Surprizing Comfort.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Pernicious Jilt. (Behind.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Twas reported, Madam, 'twu'd have suddenly been a Match between you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What he may report I know not: But when I marry him, assure your self it shall be when I despair of any one else.—A dull constant Ass born to hear the Burthen of a slighted love. A lump of Lime only to be fir'd with cold Water.—Think no more of him, had I not vow'd a single life, your Merit above the world wu'd charm me into Marriage. But since that Blessing is deny'd me, let me at least live happy in your Friendship.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: By Heav'n her very words to me. [Behind.]

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Now! I have enough! (Drops his Handkercher.) Friendships too cold a Clime, our Mutual Happiness can never flourish there: No! Madam, 'tis only loves warm Soil that ripens all the Blooming joys of life, and makes that life, but one Eternal Harvest.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: So close! I want Patience.
Madam, your Humble Servant!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ah—! (Shricking.) I'll swear my Lord you frighted me.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I don't like his coming in that way.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I thought, Madam, Mr. Longville of all Mankind had been your Aversion, and that nothing but his being my friend cou'd make you endure the sight of him, I hope you think better of him now, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What Devil brought him to surprize us in the only Guilty Minute. Nay I must confess my Lord, I did not think him so unpleasing, while he was your Advocate.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: O! then he was Kneeling for me all this while!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Umh!—a—ay! my Lord! (Faultring.) Jesu! you don't think it was upon his own account! This was a lucky Turn.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: How she fastens her self in the Noose. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Methinks, Madam, he over-did his Part! To Press his Arguments in melting Kisses upon your Snowy hand, those were too warm for Friendship.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O' my soul he's jealous, Mr. Longville! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I ne're was jealous: I found you false before you gave me leave to doubt you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You are serious, my Lord! (Affecting a Surprize.)

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Had you been ever so with me, I had not found my self your Fool so late: shu'd I talk with you I shu'd still appear your Fool: For no one sure can part eternally (as I must now) with the hopes of his desir'd Happiness, without a Painful Thought; and I am loth to expose my weakness: I shall not aggravate your Wrongs to me: But leave your Conscience to condemn you:—Farewell for ever; and since my Truth, and Honour, are so ill rewarded, may henceforth none but Fools, and Villains Kneel before you. Going.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Stay, my Lord!—I must not lose him so: For I know the Town will never tell his story to my advantage. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: My Love shall never call me back, good manners may. (Aside.) —Your Commands, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Lord, you may be in an Error, and I hope have more Generosity than to condemn me unheard, therefore—

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Hold, Madam! I find your drift, and faith 'twere too Barbarous, shu'd I betray you to a farther guilt by suffering you to excuse what you have already shown. No! Madam, my ends are Answer'd, and now 'tis time the Jest shu'd go no farther.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: To throw aside the mask of love, and show a Bare-faced Friendship, and to tell you, that I never lov'd you, ne're admir'd you, nay always had an ill opinion of you: that I was jealous of your affected coldness to my Friend, and therefore feign'd my self his Rival; that you with Artificial Blushes have approv'd my Passion, and seemingly (for I ne're thought you real yet to any one) plac'd me nearest to your heart: where Heav'n knows I never wisht my self, I only search'd it for a Friend, and faith, Madam, had I found him there, I had retir'd with joy, I ask your Pardon for my Intrusion into your Favour, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Confusion! Trick'd! betray'd! caught in the very snare that I had lay'd for him! Now the Malicious Town will Triumph!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: May my Lord go, Madam!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Lord, this usage ill becomes your Honour, or my Quality; as for the insolence of your Friend, I cu'd expect no better from a Rejected Lover.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I saw no great signs of his Despair, Madam: But to satisfie you better, I have over-heard every word you have said this half hour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Then I am betray'd indeed! That Devil Longville has rescued him from Ruine: Confound 'em both, I shall never dare to show my Face agen!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Really, Madam, I can't blame the Judgment of your Belle-Passion: For Gallantry, Equipage, and Grandieur, are prev • iling Orators.—Hey! let my Men wait all without, I'd have the World know where I pay my Devoir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Fellow! scornfully.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Sir I have nothing to say to you! Pray be gone.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why in such a Passion, Madam!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Lightning blast thee.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Take not a Womans Anger ill! Turns short, and sings.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Curse of my Treacherous Folly, that urg'd me to believe his Passion Real—O that it were! Ha! Can't it be made to seem so? — A sudden thought revives me!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Well! Madam, I ask your Pardon for consenting to the Extravagance of my Friends Attempt: But if you have a Thought that can condemn me for't, now freely give it Breath: For after this you'll never see me more.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Lord you know this Apology is needless: I only desire to speak a word with Mr. Longville before he goes. smiling.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Me! Madam! with all my heart. they go together.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: (To her self.) Now Assist me all the subtilty of Woman! — If there's a spark of Love remaining in that Bosom, (pointing to Lrd. Lovemore.) lend me a Smile to light it into Jealousie! What tho' his Flame be out, I have seen a dying Taper kindled with its own Smoak! — O! to make him burn agen, and work a brave Revenge upon this Wretch, this poor Extinguisher!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Madam! I have not heard you say very much all this while!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Come a little this way! shee seems familiar with him.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What the Devil has she got in her Head now!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! I don't like that whispering! S'Death she smiles on him!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: (Aloud) Never fear that! if he offers to draw, my Servants will part you before there can be any Mischief.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: S'Death! I don't understand you; hark you, Madam!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I know my Dear, what you mean; I will tell him all my self.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ounds! my Dear!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Prithee! Ridiculous! — Why shou'd we conceal it longer! Both he, and the World must know it in a little time.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: S'Death! She racks me!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: And me! aside.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Come! I am weary of my odious part: Beside, my Lord has no Reason to take it ill of you, since, as you own, he only wanted a Pretence to leave me for another.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Unheard of Treachery! aside.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I find Madam, you are designing me a Kindness, and Faith 'twere pity to baulk this fit of your good Nature. Pray go on, Madam, Methinks I wou'd fain have my Lord satisfied—What a Jilt you are. aside.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nay, I am resolv'd he shall know all—In short, my Lord, what you over heard there, was his particular Request to me to give you a Pretence for leaving me, and at the same time to conceal his real Passion, by feigning a feign'd one to me; and since I find, my Lord, that you have been long engag'd elsewhere, I tell you this to let you see I have been before hand with you.

sp.speaker: L. Lev.
sp.p: Confusion! he has been my secret Rival! Sure Hell n • 'er form'd so close an Artifice! aside.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ah! Dear Madam, I am oblig'd to you: But faith this won't do: Your humble Servant—Come my Lord!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: No Sir! don't think it shall: Tho' I have been this Ladies Ass, I will be yours no longer: I don't wonder now you thought her false to me!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: My Lord! amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Fye! Mr. Longville, no more of this! The Farce is over now, and I can't bear any thing from you, that looks so like indifference.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Confound your Kindness!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nay I vow I ask your Pardon! And since I find you are so unwilling to Reveal it, 'tis not gon so far, but we may blind him still: 'Tis but your seeming to use me ill again: Now begin to rail at me!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Stupendious Impudence!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Insinuating Slave! aside.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So! so! very well I'll swear! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Fury! Monster!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Better yet! O! I shall dye!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Harpy! Fiend! Devil!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Admirably well acted, I'll swear—so now take up a little.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I shall observe you, Madam!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: So soon Instructed Sir! aside.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I find there is no Remedy but Patience! the more I strive, the faster I am entangled—my Lord I must confess I cannot wonder at your Amazement. But as a Token of my Innocence— offering his Sword to Ld. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Be sure you keep your Countenance. aloud in his Ear.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: S' Death! am I become your sport!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Exquisite Devil! Astonish'd.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: No Sir, keep your Sword! You may have occasion for it — Farewell— Exit Ld. Lovemore, hastily,

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Confusion! he is undone! I've ruin'd both my self, and him! Something must be thought on speedily.

div.stage: Leonora looks gravely on Longville, and on a sudden burst into a loud Laughter.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! he!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Very well! Your Tune may be chang'd, Madam, my Wits won't be idle.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Wit! from thee! I shall as soon dread it from a Country Parson: Go Sir, to your Friend, he'll thank you for the Pains you've taken, and certainly admire your Wit! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Damn her she has unman'd me, almost work'd me to the Thoughts of a Revenge. muses.

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.p: Ha! I see my Mother coming! I'll set her upon him to heighten my Triumph.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Well Child, have you done with Mr. Longville yet?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O Madam the saddest Accident! Poor Mr. Longvi le's Distracted! Look how he Chaffes and Frowns! His Fit's upon him now! He abuses ev'ry one he speaks to, has almost frighted me out of my Wits.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: I'll swear I thought his Behaviour this Morning was a little strange; good lack! Can't you guess at the Occasion Child.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I don't know what to think, Madam, but my Lord Lovemore tells me you are the occasion, he says he has never been right since your Ladiship protested against a second Marriage.—Dear Madam; won't you speak to him?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Lord! that ever my rashness shu'd be the occasion of such a Misfortune! How wild he looks!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: (To Himself.) To what a plunge am I reduc'd? I am not only in danger of forfeiting his Friendship: But of his loosiing himself agen to her: My Life! my Friend! my Honour, all's in danger: For shu'd he challenge me, my Innocence will not let me answer him! If I refuse, the World may think it fear. Shu'd I fight, and Fortune put his life into my Power, ev'n the Gift of that were not enough to clear my Honour; for in his heart he'll think me still a Villain.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Well! I can hold no longer; the poor man raves. (Weeps.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It works as I cu'd wish. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: S' Death! the very thought on't makes me mad!

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: If you love my life, Mr. Longville, let me know that thought, or I shall run m • d too? (Takes hold on him.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Confusion! am I fallen into her Clutches!

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: D • a • Mr. Longville don't be thus frighted: For I had rather break a Thousand Vows, than see you in this condition: All the World shan't perswade me: For I am now resolv'd to marry you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Hark you, Madam, who puts you upon this?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Lord! wh—wh — why do you stare so? [Trembling.]

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: To hear a Woman of your years talk thus: Pray, Madam, how old are you?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Why do you talk so wildly?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I say, Madam, how old are you?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Nay dear Sir, don't let my Age discourage you: For I hope still to be the Mother of many a dear child, provided I deserve for 'em by your Reasonable Endeavours.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Madam, you are now big with a false Conception, and will certainly miscarry of it. (Going.)

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: O I can't part with you, while you have a thought that wrongs my Honour. (Holds Him.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That's impossible! thy Face protects it: Age and Ugliness lye intrencht in thy hollow Cheeks, and bid defiance to all scandal: yet thou art every day displaying thy Colours of White and Red, to make the World believe thou art in action still.—Come! come! Madam, you had as good give over beating up for Voluntiers: For the Devil a Man will you raise to starve in those Winter Quarters. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ha! Gone! I am afraid, Madam, this Madness is affected: I really believe, because I refus'd his Addresses, he was resolv'd to be reveng'd by affronting your Ladiship and me.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: How! His Addresses! Nay then I'll be reveng'd! Olivia shall revenge me: For I will go, and tell her of it immediately.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O! Madam, I have such a story of him for your Ladiships Ear.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Prithee! let's in, and have it at Dinner. Exit Lady Manlove.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What a malicious Devil is this Longville? To rob me in one minute of the Pride of all my Conquests. Why let him go! I have still the Glory of a Brave Revenge to Boast! Perhaps his life may pay for't: If all the Devils in our Sex can ruin him, it shall! An unform'd Mischief lyes rowling in my thoughts, and tells me I shall Triumph! That Men shu'd ever match their Wit with ours! What but a Woman cu'd thus fool'd his treacherous Friend, and a Resenting Lover? Lovers or not, we still defye Their Boasted sense! But when they love, what Slaves, what Wretches do we make 'em? How easie 'tis to look 'em into ruin?

q.l: If they wrong us, we seek a Brave Revenge,
When we are frail, we make the Injur'd Cringe,
Our Eyes prevail, when sullen Reason's deaf,
Our Tears perswade 'em,—and the Fools believe;
While false, we Lordlike reign, and only find,
'Tis being true, that ruins Woman-kind. Exit.

div.trailer: The End of the Second ACT.

div.head: ACT III.
The Scene a Dining-Room in Longville's House.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: PRithee, my Dear think better of him.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I never shall! he won't give me leave to do it—If he valued me, or took any Pleasure in my Commands, he wu'd take less in my Lady Manlove's Company, he lives there I think.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Bless me, can you be jealous of him with a stale Widow, he is no younger Brother, my Dear!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: He is a Man, consequently a thing that's vain, and loves to be admir'd.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: There are such Out-cast Fops indeed, who rather, than not be lik'd at all will take up with the Common Favours of an old Lady. But I can't think my Brother so necessitous a Lover, having already merited the good opinion of my Dear Olivia; nay I must believe he merits it, or you wou'd not so often have confess'd it.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I am not asham'd to own my self in an Error.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Your greatest Error is your Doubting him: Come! you shall think better of him, 'twill oblige your Friend: I am in Pain while you are thus severe to him: Have I no Power? Dear Olivia.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Kind Emilia! I cannot think thou wou'dst use that Power, did not thy Brother's Innocence persuade thee: O! I cou'd devour thee for thy Generous Faith to him. [Kisses her.] And if I love him well 'tis for his tender care of thee.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: He loves me best, in loving you so faithfully: Indeed he loves you. I am sure he does: For he has taught me hitherto, to avoid most Womens Friendship: But when I mention'd you! O! How he press'd me to my applauded Choice, and charm'd me with your Vertues.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: This from a Friend assures me to be happy: But is he not to bl • me my Dear?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Take it on my word not now: 'Tis a Business of Concern, that keeps him there, I want time to tell you what: Have but a little Patience and his return will satisfie you: Prithee be Good Humour'd, he won't be long I am sure! Here's the Harpsicord to Divert us in the mean time. Come! I will have a Lesson.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Prithee, I can't Play. [Ʋneasie.]

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Nay, I won't Court you, but make you! There! There! Gentlewoman. [Pulls her to the Harpsicord]

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Lord! I am n't in Humour now.—Prithee! Can't you send to my Lady Manlove's.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Humh! I find she sticks in your Stomach still.— Who's there?
Step to my Lady Manlove's in the Pellmell, and tell my Brother here is a Lady stays for him,—make hast. Exit Servant.

div.stage: [Olivia smiles on Emilia, and begins to Play.]

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: O! have I put you in Tune, Madam.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Nay, nay, you shan't give over so! I will have a Song too.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Nay if I sing—

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: If you don't, I shall be very angry, Madam.

lg.l: Since you'll allow no Lover true,
Are not we Women Fools than to be so?
Belinda smiling thus the Sex betray'd.
Men have their Arts, and we have Eyes,
We both believe, and both tell lyes;
Tho' they a Thousand Hearts pursue,
We love to wound as many too.
Yet still with Virtue! virtue! keep a Pother,
And thus are Fools to one another.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: What is not this Fellow come back yet? Well! I am out of Patience.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Prithee what time did you appoint my Brother, that you are so uneasie?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I sent him word to meet me at my Father's at three this Afternoon, where I find he has neither been, or left any word for me.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Why what a Clock do you take it to be now?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Past the Hour I am sure: 'Twas after two before I came from Kensington.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: To see how slowly hours move with Absent Lovers: Now my Watch wants above ten Minutes of Two.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I don't know, I am sure it's past Three by my Inclination.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Prithee set it back a little: But see here is the Messenger: Now I suppose, you may let it go as it will.
Did you see my Brother?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, Madam, he has not been there this Half-hour.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: And don't they know whither he went.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, Madam: But my Lady Manlove desires to speak with your Ladiship, and bid me tell you, that perhaps she can satisfie you; if your Ladiship stays here long she will wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
