sp.p: No! no! I'll go to her, she will be an Hour a setting her self out: Come my Dear will you go along with me: Well, I am sure I shall hear no good of him.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Perhaps not, if my Lady Manlove has any thing to say of him. But however I will bear you Company: How did you come, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: O prithee make haste, my Coach will carry us. Exeunt.

div.head: The Scene Changes to Locket's in the Street.
div.stage: Enter Lord Lovemore in a Chair.

sp.speaker: L. Lov. to the Chairman.
sp.p: HOld!— (To his Servant.) step into Locket's, and enquire if Mr. Longville be there. — Don't say I wou'd speak with him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He is not there, my Lord, but they expect him every Minute.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Set me down.—There. Gives them Money.

sp.speaker: Chair.
sp.p: God bless your Honour. Exit Chairmen.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: If he comes this way I am sure of him.—But I am not sure of my Revenge in so publick a Place.—Let me see how shall I manage him. (Muses.)

div.stage: Major Rakish appears in the Bellcony Smoaking.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: A Hey! Dog! Son of a Whore! some more Wine here, Quick.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Here Tom! Dick! speak there! — Coming Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Who's that, my Lord Lovemore! Od's-heart we have stay'd this Hour for you! Where's Charles, Man? where's Charles?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: He won't be long, I wait for him: We'll be with with you presently.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Prithee make haste, Odsbud the Rarest Haunch of Venison, and Colliflowers—A Hey! Dinner there. (Exit Major.)

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I have thought on't! there I shall be sure of him. Hey! Waiter!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Have you e're a Back-Room empty?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, you may have the Lion.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: When Mr. Longville comes: Be sure you show us there.— (Exit Waiter.)

How Basely has this Man betray'd me, had he like a Generous Friend to me confess'd himself my Rival, I then had only griev'd to have found him so, and thought that Leonora's Charms were irresistible: But like a Traytor thus to throw a foul Aspersion on my Love, secretly to insinuate that I am false to her! O 'tis the Basest lowest act of Groveling Treachery! Had he ten thousand lives I wou'd serve 'em all to my Revenge. Ha! he is here, I'll take him while my Resentment's warm.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I am glad to find you here, my Lord, I wou'd fain speak with you.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Come, let's walk up; we are stay'd for.
(Within.) Welcome Sir! Please to walk this way Gentlemen.

div.head: The Scene changes to a Back-Room in the House. A Waiter shows in Lord Lovemore, and Longville, and Exit.
div.stage: Lord Lovemore claps too the Door, and locks it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: HA! so sudden! Nay then 'twas well that I prepar'd my self.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: You guess my meaning Sir?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I apprehend your Error, and it grieves me.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Dost thou not blush?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: For what? because a Woman has out-witted me? If so my Lord, your self shou'd change your Colour.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I find thou art grown an hardned Villain.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: When your amazing Jealousy's my Judge, the worst of Villains. My Reason is in Health, and construes nothing ill from a distemper'd Friend.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Have I not Reason to be sick of thee?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thus far you have: When as a Friend I offer'd you a Cordial for the Infection of Leonoras Eyes: She in Revenge perswades you 'tis a Poison: I cannot blame your Fears: But till you find the Poison work, believe me still your Friend.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: So Artful, Sir! You wou'd have me Respit my Revenge till you have fixt my Leonora, Married, and Enjoy'd her! Confusion! Didst think I wou'd resign her tamely to thy Arms? Monster no! Thou ne'er shalt Triumph there till thou hast made thy way through me—Draw— And if thou hast any Title to her Heart, dispute it like a Man: For I am now resolv'd, but one of us shall live to claim it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: By Heav'n you are on the brink of Ruine, hear me: but — you know it is not fear that holds my Arm.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis worse! Thy close designing Craft; Thy Aim is still to Cheat me with a pretended Friendship! No more! I will not give thee time to form a new Evasion: Therefore Draw; for I have sworn to satisfie my Revenge, and Injur'd Love.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What if I renounce all Claim to Leonora, or bind my self by solemn Contract never to speak, think of, or see her more.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: So Tame! No! Even this is not enough to save thy Life: For tho' thy despicable Baseness now prompts thee to forswear thy Love, yet still thy foul Detraction has for ever Ruin'd mine. Leonora thinks me false, and only in Revenge has favour'd thee: I slight thee as a Rival: But as a Villain am resolv'd to end Thee— Guard thy Life.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Give me but an hours Time to prove your Error; Nay, but a Moment now! Hear me but speak!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Draw, or I'll nail thee to the Ground!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nay then!— By Heav'n I will be heard,

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! What means the Villain!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Stir not as you prize your Life— And now I'll own my self a Villain! I mean for my betraying Leonora, had
not you been blind to your scorn: For though I knew her false, I took too base a way to prove her so: Nothing cou'd excuse me but the height of Friendship! Were what I have done presented on a Stage, all generous Souls wou'd hate me for the part I have acted: But since my good Intention is so ill rewarded by your ungrateful Jealousie, I here retort the Villain back; and in defiance of thy Rage, thus Arm a Madmans Frenzy.

I wou'd answer with my Sword, but, as you know, being disabled by a late Wound in my Arm, I thought if you were resolv'd on Death, this was the surer way too for one of us to find him: Now make your choice my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Now! thou art a worthy Rival! No more, but Both retire; and then advancing, as our Fate directs us, never let us meet agen. They Advance from each end of the Room, and fire on one another; Lon. Falls.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Now Leonora's Yours! Fly my Lord, and save your self.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: No! I have kill'd thee bravely, therefore will not fly: Thy Life was forfeited to thy breach of Friendship; and tho' the Law has no regard to an honourable Revenge, yet there's a higher Power that controuls its Rigour, where I am sure so just an Action will have Mercy.
(Within.) Open the Door there! Open the Door.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Friends, my Lord! your Friends.
(Within.) Hey! A Lever there! Let's break it open.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: You shall not need. (Ʋnlocks the Door) Now Gentlemen you may enter.

div.stage: Enter the Major, Y. Rakish, a Gentleman, and several People of the House.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Why how now my Lord! What the Devil have you more Stomack to a brace of Bullets, than a good slice of Venison? A Pox on your forc'd Meat, odsbu'd I don't like it.—Why what's the matter Man?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Ha! Longville Wounded!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, how came this?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: That you shall know another time; let it suffice I own my self the Man, that Kill'd him; I Glory in the action, and will answer it to the Law.— Pray Gentlemen keep out the Crowd, for I wou'd not give Fools a Holyday before my time.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Clear the Room there!—You Dog! Run for a Surgeon quickly, — let's see, what is there no Hopes? Here! here! Jacky help him up a little— (They set him in a Chair.)— What a Devil is he quite gone! Plague on't, now must I go to Law with his Executors for my Five hundred Pound: why, what an Unfortunate Son of a Whore wert thou to leave it in his Hands.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Any Hands, but yours dear Daddy. Ha! he stirs.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ah! Dear Charles, the Five hundred Pound! What hast thou done with it? speak! speak! my dear Boy, where is't?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: S' Death, Sir, is that a Question to ask a Dying Man?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It is too much Money, Sir, for a Dying Man to run away with.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Here, some fair Water there.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: (Rising.) I am oblig'd to you for your Care, Gentlemen: But at present there is no occasion for it.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What a Devil does he walk before he is Dead?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Why how now Charles! Alive agen, and unhurt! How is't?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! what Devil has instructed him thus to baffle my Revenge?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
And now my Lord, I'll prove my self agen your Friend: I fear'd your Jealousie wou'd break into some Extravagance; and to deceive its Rage, took care to Arm you with an Unloaded Pistol: I knew the Noise wou'd bring in People to prevent a sudden Mischief, and give me time to clear my Innocence; which if I now don't convince you of in an Hour, Dare me to the field, if I refuse you then, think me a Villain still, and Post me for a Coward.—If you believe I speak this out of fear my Lord, you wrong your Conscience: For I have giv'n Proof,
when your occasions call'd me, that I esteem'd my Honour more than Life

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I own it true, and 'tis that thought encourages me to embrace the Offer, in the mean time I will struggle with my Reason to believe thee Innocent.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Look you, my Lord! Tho' I know nothing at all of this Business, yet I know Charles is a very Honest Fellow, and I'll stand by him. If he must have occasion for a second, Odsbu'd old Dick's his Humble Servant. (Claps Lon. on the Back.)

sp.speaker: Y Ra
sp.p: Nay then, Sir, little Jacky's oblig'd in Honour to be my Lord's.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Well said, Wickedness! There's an Ingenious Dog! now, rather than be out of mischief, will he fight with his own Father.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Why saith Old Gentleman, you have liv'd out of all Conscience, and unless I make an Hole in your Lungs, I find I shall never make one in your Estate.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: It's a Good Lad!— Why thou wilt have a Thousand Pound a Year, my little Jacky, if thou art not Hang'd before I die.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Gentlemen! your Dinner is upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Come, come, walk in my Lord, I am resolv'd to see you Friends agen,

sp.speaker: L Lov.
sp.p: I shall be glad of an Occasion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Fear not, my Lord, my Honour is engag'd to give it you. Exeunt.

div.head: The Scene Changes to Lady Manlove's House.

sp.speaker: Trif.
sp.p: WEll Lettice, this is a Rare Family we live in: For what between the Amours of my Lady Leonora, and the over-fondness of her Mother my Lady Manlove, we are in a very fair way of making our Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p:
Nay, for my Part, I have no reason to complain: For
if I have but a mind to a particular suit of Knots, or a Gown of my Ladies, 'tis but commending her Complexion in a quite contrary colour, and the Business is done; and if you have but a new Intrigue to entertain her with, her Souls your own. O law! did I never tell you how she serv'd an Amorous Book of Major Rakish's t'other day.

sp.speaker: Trif.
sp.p: No Prithee! how was it?

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Why you must know, last Week she Borrow'd a French Novel of him, and being told there was one deadly smutty Page in it, she very discreetly beg'd him to double it down, that she might be sure to avoid it: But when she gave him the Book agen, that poor Page was more Thumb'd and blurr'd, than the beginning of a School boys Accidence.

sp.speaker: Trif.
sp.p: Ha! ha! and no doubt but she took more Pains to get it by heart. But hark you Lettice, now you talk of a School-boy, how stands you Affair with my Lady's Son, Mass Johnny?

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: O in a very fair way, I can assure you: He pretends to comply with his Mother's Design in going to St. Omers: But I know it's only his cunning to try whether or no I shall be concern'd to part with him: Now I am unwilling to loose him by being too foreward, and am resolv'd to drive things to an extremity before I consent to marry him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: How! to Marry him, why I thought you only design'd to make a Fool of him.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Why that's making an Husband of him I think: O Dear, here come's my Lady, I'll tell you more anon. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter a Gentleman with Olivia, Emilia, and Lady Manlove.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: (to Olivia.) What I have told you, Madam, is word for word, as I had it from Mr. Longville's own mouth; Well, Ladies I have perform'd my Duty, and now must beg your Pardon; I left him at Locket's, and promis'd him to return immediately.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Cousin, Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you, I am glad you have eas'd us of our Fear.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Madam, Your Humble Servant. Exit Gent.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Now, my Dear, I hope you are satisfied of my Brother's Truth.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: It seems my Lord is not yet satisfied of his Friendship.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: But you hear he has engag'd to convince him of it in an hour.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: When he does that, I shall know how to settle my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ladies, Your Servant: I hope you have heard Mr. Longville is alive still.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and I hope will live to give a Proof very shortly both of his Love and Friendship.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: As for his Friendship that I can't answer for: But I confess I have no reason to complain of him as a Lover.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: How, Madam!

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: You have no reason to complain of him as a Lover!

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O Dear Ladies! Is that such News to you? Well I find of all People your near Relations never trust one another with their Love-secrets.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: This Insolence is insupportable! (Aside.) Pray, Madam, what Proof has my Brother ever given of his love to you?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nay I can't swear, that he has given any certain Proof, for now a days Men offer Marriage, as their Interest directs them, not their love.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I see Women are more vain, than Men are false: Now, Madam, I am concern'd, and I must tell you, you are the last of Womankind cou'd make me so far jealous of Mr. Longville: I know the Race of Man wou'd fall, were only he and you alive to raise it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I see Vanity, Madam, is a raging Vice among our Sex, and when it meets with a Disappointment, it knaws it self to Envy. [Scornfully.]

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Yes, and Revenge too Madam, which I find is now your aim for Mr. Longville's disappointing you of my Lord Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: All Happiness, Madam, is Opinion; believe he loves you, and you are happy still.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: No, Madam, let Opinion be your security, I will be contented with Demonstration: Were there no other way to satisfie my Lord Lovemore's Jealousie, I wou'd Marry him this very Minute,

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: (to Leo) Dear Madam, say all the provoking Things you can to make her pursue that Resolution, if it be but to heighten your own Triumph!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: • ow Madam! Marry him this very Minute? Why sure you wou'd nor ravish him: For I can never believe he will consent to it.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: You are not the first Lady, Madam, that has mistaken Good Manners for Love.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nor he the first Man, Madam, that has conceal'd his love with Good manners: Look you, Madam, not that I am fond of Publishing my Conquest: But if you will give me leave I will write to him this very Minute, and you shall judge what Interest I have in him by his Answer.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: You had as good let it alone, Madam, it's ten to one but he disappoints you agen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: However, Madam, you will give me leave to try my Power, [Smiling] Some Pens and Paper there.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: What are you going to do, Madam!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To write to Mr. Longville, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: [Pausing.] — I declare it she provokes me! — And dare you let me see what you write, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Freely, Madam, if you'll give your self the Trouble.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: P'shah!—Well! Madam! Pray give me leave to write to him too?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: All the reason in the world, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I am amaz'd! why, Madam, will you write to him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: With your Permission, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Sure I don't understand you! I mean to Mr. Longville!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ay! ay! to Mr. Charles Longville this Ladies Brother, I will write to him to meet me within half an Hour, at Mrs. Siams, the Indian-House here in St. James's Street, and for both our satisfactions, do you appoint him in another Place at the very same time.

div.stage: Enter a Servant with Pens and Paper.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: So Positive! This to convince you Madam. Sits to write.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p:
[to Leo.] I don't know what your meaning may be: But I am sure, Madam, my Brother will be oblig'd to you for his Happiness: You'll gain him more in one minute, as her
Pretended Rival, than half an age of love cou'd purchase him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: [Aside] Poor easie Fool! His Happiness! no his Ruin, or my Wit shall fail me. [Sits to Write.]

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: [to L. Ma.] Methinks, Madam, this is a very odd undertaking for a couple of Ladies to draw two several Bills upon a Gentlemans Heart, and both payable at sight: 'Tis well if he don't prove a true Banker, and make them wait his leisure for the Payment.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O Madam! the Fund of love is never so low, young men have always a little running Cash to supply a present occasion.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Ay Madam, but one had as good be without it. It is commonly upon very hard Conditions.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: I'll swear, Madam, there you are in the Right: For now a days a Woman can no more expect to receive a Billetdeux in Honourable love, than a Bill of Exchange in all Ready Money.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Ay Madam! You see what ill Women, and Clippers have brought us to!

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, don't lay the Fault upon us Poor Women: For to my knowledge 'tis the false men, that offer their Base love.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: But the Women—take it, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Not all of 'em, Madam, as you wou'd say your self, if you knew what severe Repulses I have given young Mr. Rakish; Nay, I can assure you the Old Gentleman, the Major too has made his Attempts: Well, Madam! If I thought you wou'd be secret I cou'd tell you more too.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Than I desire to know I find! [aside.] if you please, Madam, another time. Well—have you done, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Yes, Madam! I have finish'd mine.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I have but two words more — So!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Now, Madam, if you please we will read 'em.

body.p:
My Resolution still holds of meeting you in half an Hour (accor- to your first Appointment.) at Mrs. Siams, Dear Mr. Longville be careful of my Lord Lovemore, whom you will find it
hard to over-reach a second time: While he is deluded nothing can disturb the Happiness of your

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Phooh! She'll never send this Letter.—Come my Dear, Now let's hear yours.

body.p: The Town is in a very scandalous Story concerning your Quarrel with my Lord Lovemore: Pray let me see you at my Fathers in half an Hour: For I am impatient till I know the real Truth: Fail not a Minute, as you Prize the Quiet of Your

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: The Quiet of your Olivia! Nothing but Death I am sure will hinder him from obeying so kind a Summons.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Very well! If you'll give me leave, Madam, I will Seal it for you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: O! I won't trouble you Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No Trouble Madam: Pray oblige me. (Oli. gives Leo. the Letter.) Have you your Seal about you Madam! (to L. Man.)

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: I must know your Design. [aside.] Ay Child!

div.stage: L Man. pretends to be some time feeling for her Seal.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: [softly to L. Man.] Now, Madam, do you keep them in Discourse a little, while I alter one word in her Letter.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Ha! What word?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Instead of her Fathers, I will put in Mrs. Siams, the very same Place Mr. Longville is to meet at.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Admirable! But what will you do with your own Letter?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That I will take care by a pretended Mistake shall come to my Lord Lovemores Hands. Ask no more Questions, Madam; give me the Seal quickly.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: O! Now I have found it!—There Child. (Aloud)

div.stage: [L. Man. gives Leo. the Seal, and goes to the Ladies; while they seem to talk, Leo. alters the Letter, and seals it.]

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: There's your Letter, Madam. to Olivia.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Who's there?
Here! step to Lockets, and give this Letter to Mr. Longville! If you don't find me here, bring me an answer to my Fathers.

div.stage: (Leo. offering to seal her own Letter.)

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Hold! Madam, once more for my Satisfaction, let me see if this be the same Letter you show'd me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The Consequence wou'd have convinc'd you, Madam; but I can't blame you for believing your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: 'Tis the same. [she returns it to Leo. who seals it.) Pray let me see you send it however.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Within there!
Run with this to Mr. Longville at Lockets. (he is going) De'e hear!—stay below till farther Order. softly.
It requires no Answer, make haste agen. aloud.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Emilia! are you not amaz'd? You see she has sent the Letter! He will not meet her sure!

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I know not what to think!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Wou'd I had never sent him mine: I begin to fear her now.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Don't let her see you do, I am as impatient of the Event, as thou art.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Dear Emilia, go with me to my Fathers, I am in a thousand fears, and dare not trust my self alone.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Ladies your Servant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Dear Ladies, your most Essential humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Triffle. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Look me out a Hood, and Scarf, and Mask, and bid Sam. come to me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Man
sp.p: [aside.] I am resolv'd to Encourage her in this Design, because it forwards my Revenge upon Mr. Longville, for slighting the Advances I made him.—Well, my Dear, while you are pursuing this Affair, I'll take care to dispatch your Brother Johnny; when he is once dispos'd of, let me alone to manage the Estate; the sturdy Oaks shall bow their Head, I'll make 'em know their Mistress. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Have you my Letter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Go to Lockets, and send it up to my Lord Lovemore by a Waiter: If my Lord questions you about it, face him down you bid the fellow give it to Mr. Longville. Exit. Ser. I think my Project cannot fail: For by my Lords Resentment, or Olivias Jealousie, any way my Ends are answered: It has all the various Motions of a Clock, and Points me to the Day, the Hour, nay the very Minute of Revenge. Exit.

div.head: The Scene Changes to Lockets: Lord Lovemore, Longville, the Major, his Son, and a Gentleman are Drinking at a Table.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: ODsbu'd my Lord, you are not Merry: I am sure Charles is a very honest Fellow: But you don't look as if you were heartily reconcil'd to h • m: Pox o' these handsome young Jades, they are good for nothing but to put People out of Humour.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: You mistake me Sir, I am never Merry: And to satisfie you that I am not our of Humour, Pray Sir, lend me the Flask! Come, Sir, (to Lon.) to a right Understanding between us.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I thank you, my Lord: I don't like this Ceremony.

div.stage: Enter a Waiter, with Olivias Servant at the Door.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Is Mr. Longville here, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ay! Who wou'd speak with me?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: A Footman waits at the Door, Sir.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sir, I have a Letter for you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ha! From Olivia! [Reads] um!— um! — Let me see you at Mr. Siams in half an Hour— Humh! How comes she to Fancy that Place — Um! — Um! — Fail not, as you prize the Quiet of your— Olivia. — So kind! This is Fortunate! If I can perswade her in this Humour to make me some Acknowledgment before my Lord: Sure! That must convince him of my Innocence. (He whispers the Footman, who goes out.) Gentlemen, I must ask your Pardon: I have a little urgent Business fallen out! — And now my Lord I propose in less than an Hour, to give you the satisfaction I promis'd you.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Where shall I find you?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If you please, my Lord, at my own House.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I'll not fail. Walks apart.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, I'll make the Venison mine. There!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: O Fye! Charles! Your Club is not half this, by no means.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Let's see! let's see! (snatching 'em out of Y. Ra. Hand.) What is't? Two Guineas! Odsheart, this is too much of all Conscience! Why! What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I brought you hither!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: (Pausing.) Well! — a — I'll pay your Club, Charles: Don't forget to ask me for the Overplus.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Humh! If he does Sir, you will put him in mind on't, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Why what's that to you, Sawce! What have you to say to it?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Nay Sir, nothing at all, not I: The Guineas are good Guineas, and in my Opinion, they are in very good Hands too.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What you have a mind to finger 'em, have you? Brass! Humh!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: No Sir, I seldom meddle under five Hundred.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Odso! that's true, my little Jacky! Charles! the Five Hundred Pound, you forgot that my dear Boy.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I ask your Pardon Major: But I have lest it below: (to a Waiter.) Bid your Master send me up that Money I gave him.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Pshah! you need not give your self that trouble, Charles, I have no great occasion for it now.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Humh! That's true agen, my little Jacky! But you know a Body wou'd be sure 'tis safe! Humh!

div.stage: The Waiter Returns, and gives the Money to Longville.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: (to the Gent.) Dear Ned I must engage you to be Trustee: If the Major won't come to composition, keep it till I see you agen: My Lord your Humble Servant, Gentlemen I am yours. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.p: O that's well! but Prithee Ned, let's see, if it be right, my dear Boy.

div.stage: Offering to take it from the Gent. Y. Ra. pulls him by the Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Hark you Sir! I am considering what will be my best way to dispose of this Money.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Humh! Dispose of it didst thou say! Newgate! Humh!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, for you know these are very good times to improve ready Money in!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ay, and impudence too, my little Jacky: For now a days if a Man have but a good Brazen Face, it does not signifie whether he has any Money in his Pocket, or no.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Why therefore, Sir, I consider'd 'twas no great Matter how little you carried about you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It's a good Lady! Hark you! Jacky! —Was you never out of Countenance?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Humh! Yes Sir, for you sometimes, as last night, when you cheated me of my fifty Guineas.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: That Face will get the Dog an Estate in time.— Well! then thou hast a mind to improve this Money Jacky?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, if you wou'd but put me into a way.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Why so, I will my little Jacky, I'll tell thee what thou shalt do with it presently, let's see! what is all in Gold!

div.stage: (Offering towards it Y. Ra. steps bofore him.)

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: O! you need not trouble your self to look upon it, Sir, it's all Gold to my Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Come! Faith Major to make an end of the Business you shall ev'n divide it, that is give your Son one half in hand, and (as a careful Father ought) lay up the other, till his occasions call for it.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ay!—That is give him all, and take the rest to my self! Why really if it were not for a little scandal, a Sharper is a very good Trade, I see.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: What's that you say, Sir? Dammee! A Sharper! I suppose you have a mind to tilt for it?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I shou'd make a very Poor Dog of thee Jacky, if it were to be decided that way: that's a good look, however. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: If you think so, Sir, I wou'd have you try.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Say'st thou so my little Jacky? with all my heart — Odsbu'd I have a trick to over-reach the Dog (Aside.) Look ye Ned! Lay the Money fairly upon Table. —Now draw Jacky Scabbard, and all, my Dear Boy: For I wou'd not willingly thrust a sword into my own Bowells. I'll only show thee what old Jack cou'd do upon occasion; Judgment my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Lovem.
sp.p: How now, Major, what Fencing upon a Full Stomach?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Only Exchanging a Thrust, or two, my Lord, for a little Money.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ay! ay! For every Thrust I receive, thou shalt have an Hundred Pound, Jacky, but if I disarm thee not one Farthing.

sp.speaker: Y Ra.
sp.p: Done! Sir,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Done! my little Jacky.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Well! Gentlemen are you agree'd? shall it be decided this way?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Ay! ay! Sir, we are agreed! Come old Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Look you my Lord! Here's my Guard! Here I stand! and there's my Hat, (Throws it by.) you are ready Jacky?

sp.speaker: Y. R.
sp.p: Ay, Sir! come on!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And there's my Wig you Dog: [Flings it in his face, and disarms him.]

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: S'Death and Hell! Sir! you don't think I'll take this?

div.stage: The Major draws his Sword, and seizes the Money.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Tum! Tum! dum, &c. (Sings carelesly.)

sp.speaker: Young Rakish.
sp.p: Dammee! Sir, I expect fair Play for the Money.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Tum! Tum! dum. Keeping him off with his Sword.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Judgment! Gentlemen is this Fair?

sp.speaker: L. L.
sp.p: Faith Jack all that I can say to the Business is — that the Old Gentleman has been too hard for thee.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Nay you were Disarm'd that's certain.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: (Looking his Son in the Face.) Tum! Tum! dum! &c.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Here! Waiter, what's to pay? (Out of Humour.)

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: A Bill here for the Gentleman! Sir, my Humble Service to you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Sir, I don't care for Drinking.

div.stage: Enter a Waiter, with a Bill, and a Letter.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Here's a Letter for your Lordship.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: A Footman below, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Bid him stay.— (Exit L. Lov.)

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Here you, stay and take your Reckoning, whose Money's this?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: It's my Lord Lovemore's, Sir, and there's mine

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Why how now Jacky? What Melancholy! I find thou art a true Englishman, always dull at the Payment of a Reckoning. —Well! Hang-dog in consideration of some late Misfortunes, I don't much care if I Treat thee to Day.—There.—
Tum! Tum! dum! (Going away Singing.)

sp.speaker: Y. Rak.
sp.p: So! I find he is resolv'd to carry off the Money! S'Death, I'll try if I can bully him into Composition: — Hark you, Sir, if you are not in extraordinary haste, may I beg the Favour to know whither you are a going?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Why do'st thou ask my Dear Smock-face?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Because, Sir, I have some Reason to believe it may be to my Lady Manlove's, and let me tell you, Sir, it won't be convenient: For I am going thither. (Surlily.)

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: (Pausing.) Hast thou nothing else to say to me? Brass! Humh!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: If you do go, Sir, Perhaps you may repent it: For in Plain Terms—I shall not care to see you there.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.p: Very Good!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: You will disturb us, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Disturb you! Humh!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Then I shall grow angry, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Shalt thou!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: I hear, Sir, you make Pretences there.—

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Do'st thou!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: And I advise you as a Friend to give 'em o're.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: (Pausing.) Say no more, my little Jacky. (Going.)

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Sir, I have a great deal more to say. (Stays him)

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Say it.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, I won't bear a Rival in my Love.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Is this all? is this all? You dear Blushing Rogue you?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: In short, Sir, I find your Good Nature, and my Fortune are so very low, that I am resolv'd to Marry her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: To Marry her? very Good! — Now, but upon condition I will give thee back this five Hundred Pound, Thou wilt renounce all claim to her, is not it so my little Jacky? Come! speak, you dear Rogue.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Why look you, Sir, in consideration, that you are my Father,—and a Gentleman, that I have a Kindness for, make it a Thousand Pound, and I'll have no more to say to her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: A Thousand Pound, my little Jacky?—Wilt thou 'ba • e me nothing?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: I am always at a Word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: At a word, my little Jackey! Nay, then, for a quiet Life d'ee see, I will give thee— I will give thee — let me see! What shall I give thee?—I'll give thee! I will give thee— (Pauses.) The Devil a groat, my little Jackey.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p:
So! Now may I go hang my self: — 'S Death! is there no way to be reveng'd of this old Fellow? — Ha! — Igad my Lady Manlove has given me Incouragement! Her Joynture's worth two Thousand Pound a Year, beside the Guardianship of her Son. Let me see! Here's Revenge, a good Estate, Marriage, and an old Woman all together in one Dish: Now to consult my Stomack a little! Revenge is a pretty hollow
Bit, that's the Truth on't, and two Thousand Pound a Year is well enough for a young Fellow to piddle upon: But then agen, Marriage is Hell, and an old Woman the Devil. — Humh! Igad, and so is any Woman after a Months Possession. Pox on't, I'll ev'n humour my good Fortune, and pursue her, and so dear Daddy look to your Hits: Old! why so: much the better! wou'd she were Fourscore! For Igad upon second Thoughts, when a Man is to be noos'd, who the Devil wou'd complain to be ty'd up in a rotten Halter. Exit.

div.stage: Re-enter Lord Lovemore with the Letter open.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Confusion! Is this the Proof he gives me of his Innocence? But I'll not leave a Thought unsatisfied. Here! Waiter.
Where's the Fellow, that brought this Letter?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: He is here, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Come hither Friend, to whom had you Orders to give this Letter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: What Letter, my Lord!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Why this Letter from your Lady.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: O dear, I brought a Letter to Mr. Longville, I hope your Lordship has not open'd it.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: This Fellow told me, 'twas for me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: O Lord I am undone! As I hope to be sav'd, my Lord, I only ask'd if your Lordship was here: Because my Lady charg'd me not to give it Mr. Longville before your Lordship: Why did not I bid you give the Letter to Mr. Longville?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, my Lord, I understood him your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: O dear! I shall be turn'd away! Pray, my Lord let me have the Letter again, I'll try to seal it! O! I am ruin'd, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p:
Fear not, I will take care of thee, it requires no Answer.
Exeunt. Ha! There's yet another Proof behind, she tells him here she will meet him at Mrs. Siams, according to his first Appointment. There will I wait for him: If he keeps his word!—If! Why do I doubt it? Does not every Circumstance convince me that he will? O there is no security in Man! Here might the World expect that I shou'd curse my Stars, and raging vow Revenge: But I (so soft is my relenting Nature) cou'd weep to see how Men can damn themselves: But what's impossible to Womans Eyes? Had he not lov'd, he might have still been Honest: For he has given me Proof, in Danger and Distress, both of his Courage and Fidelity: But now with one infectious Glance of a resistless Woman, his tainted Soul breaks out in an ungrateful Villain, and a Coward.

q.l: Men may a thousand ways their Virtue prove,
Yet still be counterfeit, when touch'd with Love.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT. IV.
The Scene, Lady Manloves House.
div.stage: Enter Lady Manlove, and Father Benedic.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: MAdam vat you tellà me abote your Son, is one ver' glorieuse Action: You sall 'avè your Revard in the toder Varle: For vidout doubte de best vay to dispose of your shile is to pote 'im in de vay to Heav'n.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Why truly Father, I always had Inclination to the Church: But you must know Sir, I found my Son Johnny had naturally a quick Wit, therefore I knew a good Education wou'd spoil my Design: Now Sir, that nothing might be wanting on my side, I have taken care to breed him at a private Country School; and notwithstanding the natural dulness of his Master, I gave him a particular Charge to keep him in Ignorance: For I all along design'd him for a Churchman.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: O! Dat is vel, Madam! Ma foy! Sometime d'Ignorance in de Priestè is ver necessarie to support de Cause of de Shursh: Vor ven de Paisant see dat de Preistè doe himsel of b'leive All de Mysterie of de Religion, den de Paisant vil b'leivà too. Botè ven de Priest be Vise Man, neider de Prieste nor de Paisant beleiva noting at all.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Indeed, Father, 'tis a great Misfortune to the Church, that the wicked Layity can't be confin'd from believing according to their erroneous Reason.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: O! you say ver vel, Madam! Ma foy it vu'd be moch great deal better for de Shursh, if dey hade no Raison at all! Vell! but Madame vere is your Sone?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: He is making himself ready for his Journey: Pray Sir, let me beg of you to use your utmost Authority: For you'll find him a stubborn Creature, and very hard to be kept under.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Me warr', Madame! lette me alone, lette me alone.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Really Sir I am almost asham'd to give you all this Trouble! Pray accept of these fifty Pieces, as an Earnest of my Acknowledgments.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Ah! Fi! Madame, de Shurch no take de Money.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Nay, dear Sir, I won't be refus'd.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Umh! Vell! Madame, if you please mee vill byy your Sonè some Bookà (takes the Purse.) Vere is he, Madamè, vere is he?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Putting on his Boots below Sir: The young Rogue is so fond of being on Horseback, that nothing will serve him but riding Post to Harwich.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Dat is vell, Madame, me vill goe putte on my Bootà too.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Dear Sir, I am afraid, that riding so hard will Discompose you.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: O! Madame! Note at all! Ven de Prieste doe undertake to Promote de Cause of de Shursh, he always goe vip, and spurr, vip, and Spurr, like de Diable. — Adieu Madam. Exeunt severally.

div.stage: Enter Mass Johnny ready dress'd for his Journey, and Lettice following him in Tears.

sp.speaker: Mass Johnny,
sp.p: What doest thee dangle after me for?

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Well Squire, I knew the Time, when you wou'd ha' been glad that I wou'd ha' follow'd you: But I find now you never lov'd me. Cryes.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: It's a Lye!—I did love you, so I did!— and so I do still.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: And can you have the Heart to leave me then?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Remember the back Closet up two pair of Stairs, young Gentlewoman—Yaah! you cou'd squall lowder then, when I did but offer to see, whether you Garter'd above Knee, or no.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Why I don't Garter above Knee, you may feel here then? sobbing.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: What do I care? I won't feel there, I'll feel which way I please, or I won't stay.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: No Squire! You are mistaken in me, I am not such a one neither, I'll die before I'll be your Whore.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: And I will be Hang'd, before I will be your Fool.— Why Dick! why doest not get the Horses ready?

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: You shall not leave me then.— She hangs upon his Arm. If you will stay, I will be kinder to you: Do but try me, till to morrow: I won't cry out no more, indeed now: You shall tye my Garter, where you please, if you won't go.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Will you let's Buss you then? (Surlily.)

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Yes! in a civil way. (Kisses her.)

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Well! But will you Promise to love me now? and be free with a Body?

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: I'll love you, as long as I live, if you won't leave me. (crys.)

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Well! well! what do you whawle for?

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: I am sure 'twu'd break my heart to part with you! Pray, dear Squire don't go!

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: What d'ye keep such a Baaling for? I tell you, I won't go.— Let's Buss you agen.

div.stage: Lady Manlove seeing them, stops at the Door.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: What's here? my young Rogue, and that Impudent Quean in close Conference? — I'll observe 'em.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: But will you promise to Marry me to Day, if I won't go?

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: So! (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Marry you! ay! Poor Fool! You may be sure on't. (Aside.) But won't you forsake me then, and use me ill?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: I tell you, I won't use you ill, you Fool you.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O! I han't Patience, the Rogue's just Ruining my Design!—Why, how now, Sirrah! what are you doing there? —and you Mrs. Flirt! I'll teach you to Debauch my Son! I will you Stinking Jade you.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: What d'ee strike her far, Mother? what d'ee strike her far? You shan't strike her no more. Inter posing.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: How! Sirrah! shall not strike her? you Sawcy Rogue! I will fell you to the Ground.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Wu'll yee?—I'll try that— [He holds her Hands.] Now strike me to the Ground? Can't you? • et's see you strike me now? [They struggle.]

sp.speaker: Lett
sp.p: [Aside.] What an Unfortunate Discovery was this? to be caught just as we had agreed upon Articles: But however I don't fear him, for I know he will Marry me now, if it be only to contradict his Mother — Dear Squire don't anger my Lady so! Pray, Sir, let go.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Why, if she will be quiet, with all my Heart, I don't meddle with her. [ • ets go his hold]

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O! O! the Rogue has sprain'd my Arms, I shall not be able to stir 'em this Twelve Month.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that; Then I shall have a Cessation of Double-Fists this Twelve-Month.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Look you, Mother, I am sorry sor't, I did not design you no harm, not I: But why shou'd you offer to strike the Poor Girl so?

sp.speaker: L. M.
sp.p: Sirrah, what's that to you, how dare you justifie her?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Why may be I have a Kindness for her, what then! and look ye, Mother, to tell you the Truth, indeed I do think you ought to be acquainted with the Business, you must know I—I design to marry her.

sp.speaker: L. M.
sp.p: And dare you tell me this to my Face, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: M. J:
sp.p: Why how shou'd I tell it you behind your Back:

sp.speaker: L. M:
sp.p: Sirrah! How dare you think of such a Thing? You Jackanapes!

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Don't 'ee caal me Names, Mother, Don't 'ee caal me Names: But if I do think on't how can I help it? And Pray why shou'd not I think on't as well, as you? I suppose you thought of a Husband, and why shou'd not I think of a Wife? You have had your swinge already! Ico'd my Vather was noa Flincher, was not I born of your Body pray, and why shou'd not I get some Body upon some Body else's Body?

sp.speaker: L. M.
sp.p: Was ever heard such Impudence! Sirrah! I shall turn over a new leaf with you: Your Governour shall know, what a wicked Rogue you are! I'll make him fley your Back-side for you!

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: I don't believe you will! Ico'd, an' he meddles with me, I may chance to lay him upon his Back: He fley my Backside! He! Kiss—won't he?

sp.speaker: L. M.
sp.p: So Sir! this is very fine Language!

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Lettice, do you slip away into my Chamber, and I will come to you presently — Exit Lettice.

sp.speaker: L. M.
sp.p: O Father! I am glad you are come, your Pupill here, my Son Johnny, has been making Love to one of my Impudent Maids, tells me to my Face, he will marry her, he won't go his Journey not he!

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Lettá me alone; lettá me alone; Come, come, Madam, 'is bettre to give him de good vard: — How you do, Young Gentleman; 'ow you do? me fall be ver' Glade to 'ave de care of you.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Ay, and you had best have a care of me.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: You no feara dat; Dat is ver' vell: Now you be one good shile. (Pats him on the Head.)

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: What d'yee Tap me oth' Head for. (Surlily.)

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: O! mee lose you, Maitre Jeanny, mee lofe you.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Let my Chin alone wu'll yee? Strikes away his Hand.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Vat you mean! strikea mee! Vat you mean? mee sall 'ave de Vip for you.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Who's that you will have the Whip for? You Loggerhead you? Who will you have the Whip for, ha!

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Loggerhate! Jernie Bleu! Vat is dat Loggerhate?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: You may go look! it's such a Fool as you are.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: De Fool! a ha! me onderstanda dat ver' vell! you callá mee de Fool! Humh!

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Why don't you hear I do Dunderpate?

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Dunderpate! Je vous Prie, Madame, vat is dat Dunderpate?

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O! a very Scurrilous Name, Sir, won't you break his Head for't?

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: O! lettá me alone, Madam: Ecoutes, Maitre Jeanny: Vat vill you say, if vor de Loggerhate, vor de Fool, and vor de Dunderpate, me sall give you, one, two, tree slap of d' Shops. Maitre Jeanny, Humh?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Why I say if you give me such another word, I may chance to wipe you crass the Jaws?

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Ver' vell! vere is de Reverance you 'ave vor my Personne?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: O Lord Sir! I do Sir-reverence your Person.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Allons, dono askà me de Pardonne, askà me de Pardonne.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Ask your Pardon for what? for what? Can you tell you Owle you? Ask your Pardon— Here give the poor Boy his Hat!—There! Now I ask your Pardon —

div.stage: He strikes off his Hat, and Periwig, and discovers the Circle upon the Priests Head.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: (staring upon him) A hey! What a dickens have we got here?

sp.speaker: F. Ben
sp.p: Ah! Que Grande Malheure! vat sall me doe? Il à Decouver in a Couronne.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Undone! Ruin'd! I shall never get the Rogue to go now.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: (to F. B.) Pray Sir, What Trade are you?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: He is no Trade Sirrah: But a Civil sober Gentleman, that I have prevail'd with to be your Governour.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: He my Governour! What to make a Papish of me? Look you Mother, as for Religion d'ye see? Truly — I can't well say what I am of: But Ico'd this I know, that I won't be a Papish; It's a hard Case, if a Man must go to the Devil, he shan't take out his Sins in what sort of Wickedness he pleases: For my part I'll e'en go the way of the Flesh, I am resolv'd the Spirit shall not carry me, Ico'd I won't be Priest-ridden thither: Not but I believe this same Gentleman knows the Road as well as a Dover Post-horse: But I am not so hot upon that Journey, and so I will pull off my Boots, d'ee see.— Tall! lall! lall! (He sits down to pull off his Boots, and sings.)

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: You impudent young Rascal! How dare you offer to pull off your Cloaths? Sirrah! I'll have your Bones broken, I'll make you change your Tune.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: No! you shan't! Tall, lall, lall!

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: You sawcy Rogue! do you laugh in my Face! I'll whip your Eyes out. She offers to take F. Benedics Whip.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: No trouble your self, Madame! letta me alone! — (to M. J.) Allons! pote on your Boote, Maitre Jeanny!

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: (looking in his Face.) Tall, lall, lall!

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Vat is dat ta, la, la, la! Me say pote on your Boote!

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Ay, it's no matter for that, I won't change my Tune! Tall, lall, lall.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Hold Father, don't be too severe: I find there is no Dealing with him; we must even try what fair Words will do.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Ma Foy! Madam— me beleiva dat is de best vay.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Johnny! My dear Johnny don't be so wilful! Prithee mind what I say to thee.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Why ay, Mother, now your Note's alter'd d'ye see, I don't care if I do change my Tune.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Now thou art a dear Child! Come, that's my good Boy, prithee put on thy Boots agen; see! Here's Mony for thee: Thou shalt have every thing thou canst ask for.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: (aside.) Say you so: Ico'd then I'll serve you a rare Trick: That Money will buy Lettice a pure Topping to her Wedding Cloaths. Why look you Mother! Because you give me good words now, if you'll give me that Purse, d'ye see! and make Vather Baald Pate walk down stairs, I will put 'em on agen.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: But will you promise me to go your Journey too?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Pooh! I will, I tell you.—Why don't he go?

div.stage: (He sits upon the Floor to put on his Boots.)

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Dear Father, don't let us cross him in this good Humour: Pray be gone.

sp.speaker: F. Ben.
sp.p: Vid all mine 'art, Madame, Maitre Jeanney me be your ver' humble Servant. (exit.)

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Why dost thou sit upon the Floor Johnny?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Pooh! What does it signifie? — Where's the Purse, Mother?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: That's a good Child: Put on the t'other Boot, and thou shalt have it.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Pshah! —Why there 'tis!—You see what 'tis to be Civil to a Body.—So! Now give's the Money.

div.stage: While she talks to him, he steals a Gimlet out of his Pocket, and fastens her Gown to the Floor.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Well, but will you promise to get on Horseback, as soon as you have it?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: What d'ye think I wou'd tell you a Lye, Mother, and look you in the Face o' this Manner?

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: That's my dear Boy, there 'tis to do what thou wilt with.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: (Rises and pulls off his Boots agen.) Tall, lall, lall!

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: How now! What does the Fool mean?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: No Fool, no Fool Mother.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: You wicked Villain, I'll— (Offering towards him, she is held by her Gown.) Ha! What's here! Hark you Sirrah! Rogue! What's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Why, that's because you shou'd not follow me! Look you, Mother, always tye a mad Bull to a Stàke! tall, lall!— and there's my Tune agen for you now. Tall, lall, lall!

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Was ever Woman plagu'd with such a stubborn Rascal? What shall I do— (endeavouring to free her self.) O! how the Rogue has ramm'd it in? —Who's within there? If I live I'll be reveng'd! I'll marry the lewdest Fellow about Town, nay the most notorious Rogue of a Lawyer, but I'll keep his Estate from him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Major Rakish, Madam, and his Son desire to speak with you.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: They cou'd not take me in a Better Time, neither of 'em shall want Encouragement; Here, Prithee undo this.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: O Dear, Madam, this is Master Johnny's Gimlet, I am sure, it is the very same, that he tackt Mrs. Triffle, and Parson Waggish together with.

sp.speaker: L. M.
sp.p: Where is the Rogue? did you see him?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, he just now put Mrs. Lettice into an Hackney-Coach.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: And did he go with her?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, Madam, he is some-where about the House.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: If he offers to go out, be sure you Dog him, and bring word immediately.—Go, bid the Gentlemen walk up.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: They are here, Madam. [Exit Servant.]

div.stage: Enter the Major, and Young Rakish.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Madam, your most Humble Servant: Odsbu'd! It is a Month since I kiss'd your Ladiships Hands. (Offering towards her Y. Ra. steps before him.)

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: It's an Age, Madam, since I did; therefore, as a long absent lover, ought to do it first. (Catches her Hand.)

sp.speaker: L. M.
sp.p: O Dear, Sir, I'll swear you Hurt me.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Can there be harm in such a Tender Grasp of Love? Madam, your Raging Charms bound like a Rowling Deluge o're my Soul, and choak me with Excess of Passion! Ah! the very Pangs of Death are on me, I beat and struggle like a Drowning wretch for life, and these my last Convulsions.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Uumh! (Aside.)

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: (Aside.) Well, I really believe I might have satisfaction enough in such an Husband, without considering the Pleasure of Revenge.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: (to Maj.) Will you make it a Thousand Pound, Sir?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: 'Oones you Dog, I'll lay your Head upon both your Shoulders. (Apart to Y. Rakish.)

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: (Turning quick to L. Ma.) O take me to that Healing Bosom, wrap me in the warm folds of Love, feed me with the Balmy Sweets, that flourish there, give me new life, and nurse me to an Infant Dotage.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: (Aside.) O! I shall Faint, I am not able to contain my self!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: [Softly to Y. Rak.] Jacky, Thou shalt have an Hundred Guineas, Prithee, let her alone, my Dear Boy.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: [Starting back he jostles the Maj.] Where am I? Sure 'tis Elysium! For Mortal Flesh, cou'd never feed so high, I surfeit with Delight: my Soul's all over Bliss: my Ravisht Senses ake with Pleasure, and I grow faint with Gazing.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O I die: I die: [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Jacky, my Dear Jacky, thou shalt have five Hundred Pound.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Thus let us ever live; thus blest with one Perpetual Round of Circling Pleasure, still Fainting with Excess of Love, and waking still to new Reviving Joys.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: 'Ounds, how the Rogue has dissolv'd her?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: You see, Sir, what Posture my Affairs are in: Nothing but a Thousand Pound can forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Say'st thou so my little Jacky? [Steps between 'em, and Draws.] Then there lies your way, down Stairs Dog: go, get you gone, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Ah, for Heav'ns sake, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: O don't be frighted, Madam, I'll tell you the Business— You must know, Madam, there is a Young Lady here in the Pallmall, of a Prodigious Fortune, whom it seems my Father here, positively designs I shall marry, or he will disinherit me; and so let him, Madam, if he pleases, for my part, I confess my Soul, and Blood, Madam, are intirely Devoted to your Ladiship; and if I were to die upon the spot, Madam, I solemnly declare, Madam, I wou'd not renounce one tittle of that Etern • l Passion I have avow'd for your Ladiship's most inde •• b •• Perfections. [Bowes, and Ogles her.]

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Umh! [Astonisht.]

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O Fye! Sir, This is most inhumane to force your only Son to marry one he can't love: Come, Sir, for my sake spare him: Pray put up your Sword.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Well, Madam, for your sake d'ee see I—I will sheath my Indignation: But by the Pleasure of Drinking all this is a more Notorious lye than ever came out of the mouth of an Irish Evidence:—But now, Madam, to the Business I came for: Look you, Madam, if you and I make a match, d'yee see; you must expect every ten Months for the first seven years Twins, Madam,—I always get Twins—That whelp's a Twin, Madam, and the Product of my Juvenile Recreations.

div.stage: [Young Rakish all this while makes Love in dumb shew behind the Major's Back.]

sp.speaker: L. M.
sp.p: Let me die! But this is Irresistibly Persuasive.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: I am very Proud, Madam, your Ladiship likes what I say to you.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Well, I swear, Sir, you have such a way— and such a Son.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Madam, I have a Thousand Pound a year clear Estate; no Children in the world but this Boy here, I shall drink him dead in a Fortnight, and then, Madam, after my death the Thousand Pound a year's your own for ever: How say you, Madam, do you like of it?

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, But now let me hear your Sons Proposals.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Pshah! a Beggar! a Poor Dog, Madam.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis true, I have not one Groat in the World, have no hopes of any thing: For the very moment that I marry you, I am sure to be disinherited: Madam, as a Friend, I beg you to believe this true, for I cou'd sooner die, than cheat you with a Pretended Fortune. [Kneels.] But if the Raging Violence of an Humble Passion have any Merit in the Eyes of Virtue, then strow your Pity here, and raise me with a kind Reviving Hope.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: What a Tongue the Dog has? (Aside.)

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O Dear, Sir, Pray rise.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Pshah, Madam, words; words! meer air; Odsbu'd, I have an Argument in my Pocket, that uses to convince a Woman sooner than all the Poetical Raptures in Christendom. Look you, Madam, the only certain Proof of a Lovers Passion is, when he parts with his Money: [Takes out a Purse.] Therefore, as an Earnest of my Affection, give me leave to lay this five hundred Pound at your Feet.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Which when you marry, Sir, you know, will be your own agen.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Hold your Peace, Sirrah: There, Madam, dispose of it at you please. [Gives it into her Hand.]

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O Dear, Major, this is an Extravagant Piece of Gallantry! — Jesu! How heavy it is—Pray, Sir, do me the Favour to hold it for me: Gives it Yo Ra.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: (Leering upon the Major.) —Tum! Tum! Dum!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I must murther the Dog! I must murther him. (aside.) Oones! Madam! I cou'd have held it for you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: (Aside.) But not so fast, as I shall.—Tum! Tum! Dum!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I was in hopes, Madam, you wou'd have made a Better use of the Money!

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O Dear, Sir, can I express my Concern for you, a better way, than by being kind to your Children.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, but not to my Rival.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Ha! Igad a good thought comes into my Head: look you, Sir, if you'l give me leave to speak a word or two in private with this Lady, I will immediately convince you, that in her disposing of this Money she has had no other Consideration than your Interest.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: What can he mean? [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Why thi • might be done Jacky, if I cou'd but persuade my self to trust thee.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Why, Sir, you shall not trust me out of your sight.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Humh! say'st thou so, my little Jacky? Nay, then I do give thee leave.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Madam, if you please— Takes her to one side o'th' Stage.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: So! Lettice is safe enough now, and I co'd let 'um lock me up an' they can.— Hey day! who have we here?— I find my Mother has a Colt's Tooth left yet, I warrant these are a couple of Suitors now! —Ico'd, I will put in with 'um— Sir, your Servant: [To the Major.] What don't 'ee know me?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Know thee? Prithee who art thou?

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Who bee I—why I bee— I bee—I co'd I don't know what to tell him, not I—why I be Mother's Zon, don't 'ee zee what I bee.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ay my Dear Lad, I see very plainly what thou art: But want to know who thou art? Who is thy Father, Child?

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Who?—I have ne're a Vather at all.—But I believe I shall have shortly: For I see my Mother there is providing for herself.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: How! thy Mother? What! is thy Name Johnny?

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: May be it is — What then.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Why then very shortly thou wilt be my Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: M Jo.
sp.p: May be not— That's as I shall like you, may be.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Odsbu'd, you young Rogue, I'll Buss you into Good Humour. [The Major offers to Kiss him, and he struggles.]

sp.speaker: M Jo.
sp.p: Let me alone, be quiet, w • 'll yee? You sha'nt Buss me. [Kisses him.] Ptah— [Spits.]—What a Plague do you Slaver one so for? You my Vather in Law? Yes, so you shall; Ico'd I'll do your Business.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: [To Y. Ra.] Why really, Sir, if this be true, I must needs own he is a very Barbarous man to use his only Son at this Rate: If you think I can serve you by Farthering this Innocent Revenge, Sir, you may command me.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Hark you, Mother.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O you wicked Rogue, are you there?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Lord, don't 'ee be angry, Mother, I come to talk with you about Business.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: O pray, Madam, give the Young Gentleman leave to speak however.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: A good sort of a Civil Gentleman; I may chance to do him a Kindness for this, I'll assure you, Sir, I will, if I can. I am Good Natur'd enough, when People are Civil to me.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Well, what have you to say, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Say,—why I understand that this Old Soldier here, is a Sutor to you, and to tell you the Truth, I don't like him: He is a strange Hurly-Burly sort of a man, he has Buss'd and Slaver'd me here, whether I wou'd or no, and has Prickled my Face, till my Eyes are all of a water.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: You Sawcy Rogue is this your Business? Know then Sirrah, that this Gentleman shall be your Father-in-Law, if he pleases: Come, Sir, if you dare trust your self alone with me, I have something to propose to you from your Son, that very nearly concerns the Happiness of us both!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Odsbu'd! Madam, you over-joy me! But has that Dear Dog put in a word for me at last then? has he? Jacky! Thou Dear Son of an Happy Dog of a Father: Buss me you Whelp, you Dear Bastard! Buss me—Od! I will remember thee for this my little Jacky! Odsbu'd I will!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: I shall give you cause I believe.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Lord! Sir! How can you let him Slaver you so! Don't it make your Nose tingle! Odsfish! he is gone away with my Mother too!— Shall I fetch her Back agen, Sir? Ico'd, an' you say the word I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: No! No Squire let him alone, he will be little the better for't.— A good sort of an impudent Face this Young Dog has, he may be useful, I'll strike in with him. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, been't you a Suitor to my Mother?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra
sp.p: Ay Squire! What do you think of me for a Father-n-Law?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Ico'd I like you very well! Better by half than that Old Soldier. What a Duce do you let him take her aside so for?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: O! it's a Design I have in my Head, Squire.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p:
Ay Sr; But do you know what Design she may have in her Hea • look you, Sir, I mean you well, I wu'd not have
you trust her too far neither, Ico'd you don't know her, Sir, you don't know her.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Well! Squire, I am oblig'd to you for your Good meaning, and in return will acquaint you with my Design upon that Old Soldier.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: You must know then. —

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: But hark you, Sir; Pray by the way who is that Old Soldier?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Only my Father, Sir.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Hoh! hoh! Ico'd then I find you eare no more for your Father, than I do for my Mother. Well Sir, but pray go on.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: About an hour hence, Squire, I shall privately marry your Mother, who in the mean time, by my Allowance is to flatter the Old Gentleman with the same Hopes, and (to revenge a severe Quarrel I have to him) is to appoint him a meeting (just when our Marriage is over) at a Friends House of mine, where I shall have a Publick Opportunity to laugh at his Disappointment, and invite him to my Wedding Supper.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Ico'd, that's well enough! O Dear Sir, shall not I beg the Favour of you to get the Parson to do me a small Job too? Od! I have a Tight young Girl here hard by that I have a main mind to be married to!—Sir—won't you speak a word to him to tack us together a little?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: How Squire! to tack you together! whom have you advis'd with in this Business? Who is it, you have a mind to marry? are you sure she is fit for a Wife?

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: I don't know Sir, but I am sure she is fit for an Husband.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Ha! Igad! there can be no harm in tying the Young Rogue of a Slipknot! This was a lucky Discovery, something may be made on't. (Asid) Well! Squire, I'll do all I can to serve you.

sp.speaker: M Jo.
sp.p: O Dear Sir! I am mainly oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Nay, I won't only lend you my Parson, but my Money too: Nay, my very Cloths; Igad I will make a Gentleman of you.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Wu'll, ye Sir? O law! (Overjoy'd.) Ico'd t • en my Mother shall make a Fool of me no longer—Sir, • s I hope to be to be married, I had rather call you Vather, t • at any man in Cursendome.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: P'sha! Pox! I'll be a Brother to the • an: (Hugs him) Prithee call me honest Jack, we'll Smoak an • Whore, and Roar, and take a Bottle together.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Is your Name Jahn? why my Name's Jahn too! Odszooks! that's brave, honest Jahn! How is't Boy? Dammee. (struts.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Why that's well said, Boy! Igad! thou swear'st like a Gentleman already.—Come, my little Rake! Now let's take one cheering Flask before the Parson does his Business; then get Drunk, break Windows, mawle the Watch, and Bed our new married Wives in the Round-house.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Ho! Boys! God a marcy Brother-Father-in-Law. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Olivia, Emilia, and Leonora. Triffle putting on her Hood and Scarf.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: There you mistake me Madam, 'tis my Amazement, not my Jealousie, that brought me hither: I own I do wonder why Mr. Longville shou'd disappoint me: But never can suspect his Honour. Speak to her Emilia, for I want Temper to conceal my Fears. (aside to Emi.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Call a Chair there. (to a Servant.)

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Then you will go Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I am preparing for it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: One serious Question more, and I have done, Madam: Do you really expect to meet my Brother at Mrs. Siams?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Jesu! Madam I can't imagine why you shou'd question that, after this Lady has confess'd he has already disappointed her: But to satisfie you, he expects me this very Moment, he is now at Mrs. Siams, — or my Servant lyes, that dogg'd him. (aside.) Look you Madam, I don't desire you to believe one word I say: But if this Lady and you will give your selves the trouble to go thither, I fancy you will find him there.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Insupportable. (aside.) Really Madam, you have an Admirable Talent.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I hope Madam, I have not been guilty of any ill Breeding.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: O fye! Madam, all that you do is with a very Court-like Air: You are resolv'd to stand it out I see.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: W • at is't you mean, Madam?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I mean, the groundless Jealousies your Malice now wou'd raise between my Brother, and this Lady — He love you! You will as soon perswade me you deserve it, Madam I know, that in ' • is Soul he scorns you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
Not so much as I scorn Revenge; I dare say, had I been fond of a Triumph, Madam, I might have had it in a Publick
Wedding. (Mr. Longville offer'd it.) But out of Friendship to this Lady, and your self, I have been content to marry him in Private. I'll out-face this obstinate Devil, tho' I forfeit my Revenge for't. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: How Madam, my Brother married to you! to you?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To me this Morning, Madam, Sister I may say. (Mildly.)

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Sister! (Angryly.)

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here's a Chair Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ladies your Servant, I shall expect you at Mistriss Siam's. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Why, have I lived to see this Day? Oh, I am despicable now! I shall be pointed at; the publick Merriment of malicious Tongues: Thou wer't my Friend Emilia; why didst thou not tell me of my Weakness, that I was Credulous, Conceited, vainly Fond to think my Easie Love cou'd fix the Faithless Temper of a Man. But thou alas! wer't soft believing Woman, like me unskill'd in Injuries: Therefore in fear of none, easily deceiv'd by every show of guil'd Virtue; married! perfidious Man.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Believe it not Olivia! Come! we'll follow Leonora: let his own words, nor hers condemn him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: You wou'd not have me see him sure!

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p:
I wou'd not have you punish him unheard: For, oh! I know his Innocence, tho' now o'er-cast, will shortly break these sullen Clouds, and gild you with a smiling Joy: Alas! my dear Jealousie's the Disease of Love, a Pain —
Which first, or last all Lovers must endure:
But none can speak the Joys, that wait the Cure. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: The Scene, an Indian House.
div.stage: Longville is discovered looking on his Watch.

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p: I Wonder why Olivia comes not, the Time's expir'd, and I am unwilling to fail in my Promise to my Lord Lovemore, who I know will be upon the Rack till I have perform'd it: But I'll have patience; For I am sure her Generosity, tho' late will furnish me with an Occasion. — Come! Mrs. Siam, what new Indian Toys have you? (He goes to the Counter.)

div.stage: Enter Leonora Mask'd at a Distance.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Longville, here first! 'tis, as I cou'd wish! — hark! I hear some body stealing up stairs! [She looks out.] Ha! muffl'd in a Cloak! O! for a Glimpse of him! — My Lord Lovemore, as I live! his Disguise tells me what he comes for, and I hope mine will help me to answer his Expectation: My first Care must be, by some seeming Accident to let him know me: my next to tell this Wretch (who must not know me) some formal Story, that may oblige him to make such Answers as may reasonably incline my Lord to think himself the Subject of our Discourse.

div.stage: [She goes to Longville, and talks with him in her Mask.]
Enter Lord Lovemore in a Cloak.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p:
So Punctual! Ha! that must be Leonora 'tis her stature! (Leonora turns back, pretending to wipe her Face, and gives Lord Lovemore a sight of it) By Heav'n 'tis she!—I saw her Face!—Wu'd I had never seen it!—Or cu'd but Dream agen the Promis'd Raptures of her Virtue: For there was Pleasure in the Vision, infinitely surpassing what we taste in any waking joy: O! there is no Happiness but in Eternal sleep! Ha! [Observing Lon and Leo.] Do
I not sleep? Rather let me think, that this is all a Dream! 'Tis liker far, Amazing! Incoherent, and Unnatural!— I find I am but a stranger to the World, another man perhaps wou'd wonder at my Amazement! Suppose I shu'd surprize him now ith' very act of Falshood? Will he not sink into the Earth with shame? must not his Conscience burn him up with Blushes? I shu'd resent this Usage, and I will; But, as a brave man ought, Despise him for his Treachery, and forgive it all! Nay more! I'll do a Friends last Duty, and wound him with the tenderness of my Resentment: But stay!—lay hold on all Advantages! something may be gather'd from their Discourse—I'll observe 'em. (Lon. comes forward with Leo.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: (Aside.) Who the Devil can this be, that is so fond of Acquainting me with her Circumstances?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Then you advise me as a Friend never to see him more?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! It must be me they talk of. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I suppose, Madam, you can't expect to be Extraordinary well us'd if you do.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Why, I am sure he loves me still.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I hope not, Madam. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hang it I believe my best way to silence his Resentment, will be to write him a Civil Letter to acknowledg the severity of my Revenge, and beg him for his own sake never to see me more.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: For my own sake, that I never will. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: P'sha! Damn her Revenge, what is't to me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What think you of it?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: O the best thing in the World, Madam, I'd advise you to step into the next Room, and do it immediately.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well! you will peruse it for me?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ay! ay! any thing to serve you

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: (Aside.) VVith your Throat: I hope, Sir, you have endanger'd it to serve me: I'll step aside, and let the Mischief work, I see it lowring yonder in that Brow. Leonora retires.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I'll surprize him now, while Leonora is withdrawn: Not knowing that I have seen her Face, possibly he will swear it was no she he talkt with!— Are you at leisure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: My Lord Lovemore!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: What is't you start at?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: To see you here, in this Disguise! you frown, my Lord!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Fye! that were to confess my Anger: Doest thou think thy self beneath it? I smile upon thee.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: When saw you Leonora?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: This Morning, I am not asham'd to mention it: But why shou'd that disturb you now? I thought an Hours time was given me to clear my self, it is not yet expir'd my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I can't think you'l keep your word with me.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I don't use to forfeit it, nor do I think it I shall, if no Misfortune cross me.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Has Leonora told you so?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Explain your self.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: If you were that Enemy you have profess'd your self to Leonora, I cannot think at such a time as this, you wou'd meet her here.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Who dares affirm it?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I saw her here, this moment saw her here with you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Then she was here with me, when I saw her not, — next time, my Lord have better Proof e're you condemn so near a Friend as I am; you saw perhaps a Woman talk with me in a Mask, who I believe might know me: For she seem'd fond of making me her confident, I listned to her till her impertinence had quite tir'd my curiosity: And this Woman I suppose your Jealousie has taken for Leonora.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Whom did you take her for?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: A stranger! I know her not, nor ever care to see her more.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! take heed! for if I prove thee in a lye, it will be then dishonourable to talk with thee.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Speak lower: while we are unheard, my Friendship teaches me to bear, but my impatient honour will be justified.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Honour! Doest thou not blush to name it?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: My Lord, it is not well to bear thus far upon my Friendship, if you wu'd have me think your meaning honest, I do demand a Reason for this Usage.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: (Amazing.) But that I cannot give my Eyes the lye, I shu'd my self believe thee wrong'd: But to confound thee in one word, give me a living reason, why I see thee here.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I came to meet Olivia here, by her own Appointment.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: S'Death and Hell; you will not tell me 'twas Olivia you now talkt with!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I mean it not, Olivia has not yet been here.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Why then are you here so Early?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Because Olivia charg'd me, as I priz'd her Quiet, not to fail a minute: Besides the time has been expir'd almost this half Hour.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Confusion! why is not she here then?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Have a moments Patience, and I'll send to her to know the reason, in the mean time, my Lord —

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Away! now thou condemn'st thy self, thy dull Invention's tir'd, and thou wants time to give it breath.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: This from another man wou'd urge me to a fatal Answer: By Heav'n now I wou'd not have you credit me! No! go on! be obstinate, believe the grossest things of me your Malice can suggest, I will not offer more to clear my self till Demonstration shakes her head, and makes you blush for these unfriendly wrongs.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: (Pausing.) I know not why I shu'd: But a resistless Curiosity tempts me to see how far thou wilt drive this: Prithee be sincere, by Heav'n if there's yet a way in nature left to clear thy Innocence: I here engage my Honour, as far as mortal Patience can to wait the issue.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Had you said this sooner, some words my Lord, might have been spar'd between us: But I have done, Olivia now shall speak for me; her Presence shall convince you where I have given my heart: That Leonora ever had my scorn, as now, I hope she has yours.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Thou talk'st with such a calm indifference, I dare not yet resolve where I shall fix my Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: No matter where my Lord, let 'em Rove, a moments. Patience will recall 'em.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I am satisfied. [They part.]

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O! I cou'd run mad, that subtle Devil has talkt him into Reason. What can it be that stays Olivia thus? —Were she here, her Resentment wu'd confirm his Jealousie, and bring the mischief to perfection. Ha! Fortune sends her to my Wish! Now to prepare her.

div.stage: Enter Olivia, and Emilia: (Leonora stops them at the Door.)

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! Olivia here too? what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: (to Olivia.) There he is, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: O! Emilia help me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
