sp.p: Now Ladies I hope you are satisfied, what Interest I have in Mr. Longville.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible! I'll not believe it scarce shu'd he himself confess it; this is some Trick! he is impos'd on! wrong'd! basely wrong'd, I am sure 'twill prove so.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Excuse him not Emilia! I'll shut my self from all the World, and never see the face of Friend agen. (Going.)

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Be not too Rash, Dear Olivia, hear him speak first: If he is not able then to clear himself, may all the Punishments his Perjury deserves be mine, if I not joyn with thee to hate and scorn him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ay! Madam! Pray stay to examine him however, not that it will be to any Purpose, for to my knowledge he will deny our Appointment, or that he has so much as seen me here.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Nay then I must believe he has not, Madam; I'll have the Truth from him Emi. goes to Lon and Oli. turns away in tears.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: (aside.) Poor harmless Thing, how it frets; I have rais'd her to my Ends. Now let her go on, while I stand by and laugh to see her forward my Revenge.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: (aside.) When will my Distraction end! Emilia thinks her Brother wrong'd! Olivia weeps to see him Perjur'd! I prov'd him guilty! And yet he starts to hear himself accus'd, while Leonora leaves him unconcern'd: I dare not leave him till these Contradictions are Unravell'd.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What Riddle's this, Emilia?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: How Brother a Riddle! Indeed I griev'd at first to find you here! But now cou'd weep to see you justifie your Crime.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Away—this Mirth's unpleasing now, where's Olivia? (He leaves her.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: (to Emi. aside.) Is not your Ladiship well? Madam, will you please to make use of my Spirits?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Fury!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Your Ladiship's Humble Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: (to Oliv.) If either may, Madam, I have most reason to complain: For I have expected you here this Half-hour.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Me! Did you expect me here?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Not with such Displeasure in your Eyes, I must confess, Madam: But I have with great impatience waited here for your Commands.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: You dare not justifie it?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You cannot doubt it, Madam,

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: This Audacious Insolence is beyond Resentment, from you it strikes my Thoughts with Horror!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: This Anger, Madam, is a Double Rack, while you conceal the Crime, that has deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Is then the Repetition of your Guilt so pleasing? Base Man! why did you send so fair an Answer to my Letter, when at the s • me time you had resolv'd to meet another Woman here? Was it not enough to wrong me by an abhor'd Abjurance of your Vows: But you must Barbarously expose me to the Triumph of an insulting Rival!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Madam, you confound me, what Rival?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Away! I have heard, and seen too much already; Reputation bids me fly you now, Farewell Ungrateful Wretch, and may the shameful memory of my wrongs lye Rooted in your • eart for ever.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Yet stay, and hear me.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Hold, Madam! before you go, give me leave to ingraft my wrongs with yours.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: (aside.) It ripens now!

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Ha! My Lord Lovemore here! This must be Combination: But I am resolv'd to find the Truth before we part: Tho' ev'n my Brothers guilt, or what's yet worse, her hateful Triumph shu'd confound me. (Aside.)

div.stage: (Emi. locks the Door, unseen, and takes out the Key.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I read Resentment in your Eyes, my Lord: Out with it! For while Amazement makes me tame, I can bear it all.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Madam! (to Oliv.) to justifie that Resentment, or to clear the Sacred Honour of a Friend, I beg you faithfully wou'd resolve me one Question: Was it by your desire, or commands, that Mr. Longville came to meet you here?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: So far from that, my Lord, that 'tis the only Place on Earth, I wisht he might avoid.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p:
Now, Sir! If my Jealousie has wrong'd you, let it
appear before this Lady, if not from this Moment let Eternal Enmity divide us.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: (Aside.) Ha! ha! ha! Poor Soul he is Dumb! Now my Revenge is perfect, and so poor! easie! cheated! Jealous Fools! Farewell! (She offers to steal out, and finds the Door last.) Ha! the Door lockt! Confusion! I am betray'd! some Devil has counterplotted me; shou'd Longville know me my Revenge is lost: No matter I am above his Anger, and am still secure in this, I'll bravely face 'em to the last. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: One word more my Lord, and I submit: But since my future Peace depends upon your Answer, I beg you wou'd directly give it me, without the least Enquiry, on what Assurance I demand it.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I'll answer you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Then give me instantly an honest Proof, that you have seen me here with Leonora?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Hell! and Furies! Is this your Question?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, your Promise.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis true, and there's my Answer. (Pointing to Leo.)

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: There! how! where, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Why there! there! Leonora's there! That's she.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: (Amaz'd!) Ha! —Nay then! There's the Devil has bewitcht us all.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: What can this Amazement mean?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Why are you surpriz'd Brother? Did not you know that was Leonora.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: — Not I! by all my Hopes of Happiness! I took her for a stranger, and as such have ignorantly convers'd with her: —

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Now Olivia!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I am amaz'd! what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That this Lady, I presume, can best inform us: Madam, I confess, I ought not to expect a Favour from you: But yet there's something might be done for both our Honours.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Sir, I have nothing to say to you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Madam, I scorn the low Revenge of a publick Triumph: But for your own sake hear me: I freely own for all you have done to me. I have given you a severe Occasion: But yet I hope the World, and you will pardon me: I knew you lov'd my
Friend, and griev'd that nothing but my exposing you never cou'd wean him from your Eyes: Now since every Circumstance convinces me, that those Aspersions I now lie under are but the Continuance of your just Revenge, if you'll but clear my Honour by a generous Acknowledgment of what you have done to ruine me; you bind us all to an Eternal Secrecy, and me in any Honourable Command to serve you with my Life.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Dear Madam, cannot this Goodness move you to an Act so just; nay, and so Glorious too for you? For no one sure can hear your Story told, but must confess your Wit inimitable, and your Revenge uncommon: No Tongue can speak its Praise like yours, whose Art first rais'd it to such a Wondrous Height.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Madam, I read your secret Triumph in your Eyes: But I am above your little Spleen.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Madam you wrong my Thoughts, what I askt of you, I was ready to receive as a real Obligation.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Then, Madam, expect none from me.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nay, then Madam, we must talk on Equal Terms; Now, my Lord hear me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Hold Brother, first let me speak: You are the suspected Criminal, and thus I charge you. — About Two a Clock this Afternoon Olivia, and I visited my Lady Manlove, where we had a full Account from a Gentleman, of your late Quarrel with my Lord Lovemore: Leonora smil'd at our Intelligence, and to our Amazement, wou'd perswade us, that you were really my Lord's Rival in her Love; adding withal, that you had lately offer'd Marriage to her: Nay, and to give us a more convincing Proof of it; she desir'd, that we wou'd see her write to you, which she did, and show'd us the Letter, wherein she appointed you a Meeting in half an Hour, here, at Mrs. Siam's. — Olivia, more out of a sportive Curiosity, than to satisfie any jealous Thought, begg'd the same Liberty, and she likewise appointed you to meet her in the same half Hour at her Father's.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: The Letters both were sent: But our Amazement yet continues: Olivia is disappointed, and we have found you here with Leonora: Now, you are free to answer.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Then Truth's in Labour of my Innocence, and thus she
is deliver'd, there's my Answer. (He produces Olivia's Letter.)

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Ha! what's here, my Lord, Emilia! see, here's the Witchcraft that has wrong'd us all! my Hand counterfeited by Leonora in my own Letter! see! she has blotted out my Father's, and interlin'd Mrs. Siams, the very same Place that she had appointed him her self.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: What have I done? my shame confounds me! How shall I dare to meet him? (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: But hold! there's one thing yet unanswer'd, if there were no Intimacy between you, and Leonora? What Encouragement cou'd she have to write to you? What Answer did you send to her Appointment?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: By all that's Sacred, I had no other Letter from Leonora, nor any Appointment whatsoever.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: No, Madam, here I am bound to speak, he never had that Letter, by a pretended Mistake I find it came to me, meerly to keep my frantick Jealousie awake; That brought me hither. (shows the Letter.)

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Emilia! Now I am happy.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: O let me embrace my Brother! At this Discovery nothing but Tears, or Madness can express my Joy.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: My dear Emilia!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: (Aside.) — Lightning part 'em.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: But pray, my Lord, how cou'd you expect to find Mr. Longville here, when you knew he had not receiv'd the Letter, wherein Leonora had appointed him?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: 'Twas written with such malitious Art, it left no room for Doubt: For here she says, she will meet him at Mrs. Siams, according to his first Appointment: I thought a second Needless to a secret Lover, which now with shame I own, I then believ'd him.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nay, then your Jealousie was just my Lord: By Heav'n I cannot blame you now: But since your Temper is recover'd, I beg you wou'd confess your Fears, and give me every Jealous Thought, that wrongs my Honour.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: By Heav'n, by this dear Embrace I have lost 'em all: O Charles! if thou hast yet one glowing Spark of Friendship in thy Heart, pity me, for those unwilling Injuries I have done thee, can'st thou forgive me?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Not while you ask Forgiveness, that's a Fault I can never pardon.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Wilt thou forget 'em?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why do you remind me of 'em?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: (To Leo.) The Door is open Madam!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Distruction seize 'em! Now my last Hopes of him are lost: I have nothing lest to hide my swelling Heart; but to affect Indifference.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Methinks I have not atton'd thy Injur'd Friendship, till I have confess'd before the faithless Leonora, that I am hers no more. — Now, Madam —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, are you going to tell me, you have lately discover'd a Secret, that all the Town has known these six Years, which is, that I never car'd one Farthing for you.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: This Obligation, Madam, was unnecessary, I needed not this Wit to work me to Indifference.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
Nor, I, your Indifference to make me angry, your whole Sex is an Eternal Subject for my Spleen: How many wretched Fops have I daily at my Feet, who think themselves much nearer to my Heart, than you: Nay, had you not view'd me with anothers Eyes, you still had been my Slave, your Love had liv'd on Air, and languisht in an endless Hope:
But I confess you bravely this may boast;
Of all the Fools, that knew me to their Cost,
You are the First, that e'er my Eyes have lost Ex. Leo.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: How easily are Men deceiv'd in Love? There's not a Vice now reigning in this Woman, but what appear'd to me the happy Conduct of un-erring Virtue: But now the false Lethargick Dream is o'er, at last I have thrown the Reins on Reason's Neck, and have out-stripp'd the lagging Mischief far behind me: But here's the careful Guide, that lead me to the Goal! O! Charles! How have I wrong'd thy Friendship, ev'n to the H • z • rd of thy Life, and Honour? The Crime still hangs upon my faultring Tongue, and Silence speaks my Shame.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: This is too much, my Lord, but if you needs will over-pay the trifling Debt, let me direct your Friendship here. [Turning to Olivia.] I have a starving Heart, that long has been this Ladie's Prisoner, here you may exert your Charity: For I perceive I owe her more, than faithful Love can pay.

sp.speaker: L Lov.
sp.p:
(To Oli.) When Lovers are so poor in Merit, Madam,
Beauty shou'd pass an Act of Grace, and take the Moiety, that Nature lends us.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: My Lord, I see no want of Merit in Mr. Longville. There needs no more to recommend his Cause: And since he has so severely prov'd himself your Friend, I'll make it not his Interest to deceive me.— Mr. Longville, if in those few Years you have talkt to me of Love, I have been too slow in my Returns, impute it not to an insensible neglect: For I have long studied, tho' unable, to repay it: And I perceive your Merit's swoll'n so high, that I am bound in Prudence now to check the Debt, and let it run no farther, your Conduct has deserv'd my Heart, nor do I dare with-hold it longer, lest I shou'd repent hereafter, that it was given so late.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: This Goodness is above the Reach of Mortal Virtue, it speaks Divinity, and like the Blessings we receive from Heav'n shou'd only be return'd in silent Adoration.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Rise, Sir, from this Moment I am yours.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Now, dear Olivia, you are mine too, the Name of Sister binds us ever.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: This is as it shou'd be, and while my Friend is so, I must be Happy.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: (Aside to Emi.) And now Emilia, there is a Blooming Hope for thee, which time can only ripen: Mean while intrust thy heart with me, and be assur'd thou ne're shalt Blush, when I think fit to part with it.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: This is beyond a Brother's love: Words are but empty Thanks: My Future Conduct best will speak my Gratitude.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thy Past has well deserv'd my Friendship: —But no more! Here is Company.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Hah! Dear Charles I am Glad I have found you, my Lord, your Humble Servant, I have brought a rare Piece of Diversion along with me.

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p: It never cou'd be more welcome; for all you see here are Friends.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it: But if you were not, I wu'd engage to make you laugh.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What's the Business?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Only my Father, and I, that's all.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Why truly that's enough to make one laugh at any time.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: O Dear, is this the Gentleman, that is so free with his Father?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: No, Madam; But I am the Son of a Father, that is very free with me, the Soul of me, my Pleasures I mean, of all the Vices this Town affords, (and thank Heaven it's pretty well stockt) I can't keep one to my self for him; He out-does me at my own Weapon, he out-drinks me, out-whores me, out-swears me, out-lyes me, out-wits me, and (which I'll never forgive him) he—out-lives me too.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Why shu'd you wish for his Death! Does not he allow you?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, all manner of wickedness: But the Devil a Farthing to purchase it.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: How can you live without Money?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Faith I begin to be weary of it, and have this very Hour laid a Design to bring the Old Gentleman to a Reasonable composition: I have Rivall'd him in my Lady Manlove, Elbow'd him out of her Favour, and have at last squeez'd him out of five hundred Pound provided I renounce all Title to her Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: And have you done it?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: For ought he knows I have, and for ought she knows I have not; in short, I neither design to quit the Lady, nor to keep her any longer, than she serves my turn.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: How so Man?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: She is now below with my Father choosing her Wedding-Gown, have a little Patience, and the Farce will begin.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: But hark you, Jack! have you taken care of her Son, as I desir'd you? I hope he is not gone to St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: No, no, I have spoil'd him for that Journey, I have Married him.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: No harm, I'll warrant you: see! here comes my Father, pray observe us—you'll all stand by me upon occasion?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: All! all!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: A word with you, Charles. [They Whisper.]

div.stage: Enter the Major, with Lady Manlove.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Wish me Joy Charles! Wish me Joy!—Hah! my little Lovemore too! Give me thy Hand my Dear Boy! Wish me Joy my Lad!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Joy! Of what Major?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Of a rare Fleshly Feather-bed, you Wag, and two Thousand Pound a Year to wallow in— Odsbu'd she's a Soucer.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Leave it to me. (
• o Y. Ra.)

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Ladies, your Servant, I protest I little thought to find so much Good Company upon such a Fortunate Occasion.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Mayn't we know the Occasion, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: I'll swear, Madam, it's such a Critical Point I don't know whether my Modesty will be able to go through with the Discovery.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: If you please to give me leave, Madam, I will help you out a little.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Ay! ay! tell 'em my little Jacky.

sp.speaker: Y. R.
sp.p: Well, Ladies, now we are all together, the short of the Business is this: This Noble Lady here generously considering my Sufferings under the Tyranny of an Unnatural Father, and being sensible that by reason of my Indefatigable love to her, I was in a perpetual danger of being disinherited, has out of her abundant Goodness piously consented to revenge me of the said Unnatural Father, by this Publick Disappointment of his Hopes, having to his utter confusion already taken to her loving Husband the Individual Person of me his lawfully Begotten Son—John Rakish.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Humh! What is all this? Do you know, Madam? What the Devil is it?

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: All truth, Sir, to my knowledg, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so take me, John Rakish Giving him her hand.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Oones, and Hell! I'll chine that Dog to the Navel. Draws.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: O by no means, Major, Prithee put up your Sword, you'll frighten the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Prithee Dear Charles let me come at him: O! He is a Bitter Dog! I can't bear him. Trembling with Passion.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Psha! Psha! Prithee be Pacified, if he must be run through the Guts, he will deserve it an hour hence, as well as now: Besides, I wu'd have you hear what he can say for himself: you know he does not use to be Tongue-tied upon these occasions.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Odsbu'd! and that's true, my little Charles! I will hear the Dog, I will hear him,—and if I am trick'd, I am satisfied I shall have the Pleasure of half a douzen rare impudent Faces, from the unrighteous Bastard to back his Roguery however.— Come hither Jacky.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Well, Sir!

sp.speaker: Maj
sp.p: Ay! That's the look! Hark you Iron-face! Art not thou. Perjur'd Rogue? Doest not thou expect to be split and broild upon the Devil's Gridiron.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: I don't apprehend you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Didst not thou promise Dog! to renounce all Claim to that Lady, provided I wou'd quit my Title to the five hundred Pound?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Ay, Sir! But I remember what Pains you took at Locket's to day to Cheat me of it: Chaw upon that, and then tell me whether you can blame me for what I have done?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O! not in the least, my Dear Hell-face! Thou hast oblig'd me to the last degree by Marrying this Lady here: The least I can do now is to settle my Estate upon thee, which thou shalt have with a vengeance, that is to say I will instantly make love to her Daughter, offer her my whole Estate for a Joynture, cut off the Intail, get a whole litter of Children, and disinherit you, you Dog!

sp.speaker: Y. R.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, there I forbid the Banes, that Lady is now my Daughter, and I will not have my Family disgrac'd, by admitting such a notorious Rakehell for my Son-in-Law: In short, your pretences are utterly against my content, and I positively declare you never shall have my Blessing.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: What a Cross Old Fellow this is now! Oones! I'd give five thousand Pound to make the Whelp my Father-in-law.

sp.speaker: Y. R.
sp.p: Come! come! Sir, for a Great deal less Money, you shall still make this Lady my Mother in-law.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Ha! say'st thou, my little Jacky! why art thou not Married thou Dear Dog, art thou not Married, Ha! speak?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: So far from it, Sir, that upon condition you will immediately sign this Paper, which will intitle me to four hundred Pound a year during life, and at your Decease the rest of your Estate, I am willing this very moment to resign the Lady • o you.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Base Man! you won't offer to sell me?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Don't you trouble your self, Madam, I'le warrant you. And to satisfie you, that my meaning's honest, the Writing is so Drawn, that unless you actually do Marry the Lady you are not oblig'd to give me a Groat.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Say'st thou so, my little Jacky? [He peruses the Paper.]

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p:
Audacious Villain! have you serv'd me thus: I will
be reveng'd.—Here Major! (Gives him her Hand.) upon condition you never do give that Villain a Groat, I will Marry you this very moment Gratis: Nay do but engage to disinherit him before to Morrow Morning, and I h • re immediately promise you six thousand Pound in ready Gold and Jewels, to satisfie any Extravagance you shall think fit.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: So!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Disinherit, Madam! Odsbu'd your Ladiships too merciful! An Audacious Rogue! to think I cou'd be such a Villain to wrong a Lady, Madam, of your unspotted Virtue! Ounds! I never heard such an impudent Proposal since I was born!—Madam! If he were now at the Gallows with the Knot under his left Ear; nay, if the Word were given for the Cart to drive away, Blood! and Brimstone! I wou'd not part with Eighteen Pence to Reprieve him.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: On that Condition I am intir • ly yours

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ounds! Madam, I'll ruin him within this halt Hour, I'll drive your Revenge quite through his Soul; nay, I'll send for the two Mischief-makers of the Nation, the Parson and the Lawyer, and make them clinch it on the other side.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What the Devil! shall we do now, Jack! was ever such a Disappointment?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Faith! Charles she has out trumpt me that's the truth on't: But I cant't lose all Man, I have Pain in my Hand still?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Her Son! her Son, Boy the Rogue has chosen me for his Guardian; He will be here presently, I'll manage him to fetch her about I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Igad that's lucky, I am glad you are sure of a Trick to save your self at last, in the mean time Jack try what a Court-Card will do, play your Impudence upon them.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Mum!

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Now Devil I am reveng'd of you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: I fancy not, Madam,—I suppose your Ladiship does not know these are the Writings of your Son Johnny's Estate, by him the said Johnny this very day stoln, out of your Cabinet: which because I am his Guardian, I will thus re put into my Pocket.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Monster! you his Guardian?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: At your Service, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. M.
sp.p: You dare not tell me so?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: O! I have a great deal more to tell you, Madam, I must ha • e a Thousand Pounds out of your Hands to morrow Morning, to put him and his Wife into an handsome Equipage.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: His Wife!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: His Wife, Madam—she has had as good an Education as your Ladyships Service cou'd afford.—Lettice I think her Name is.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Undone! Undone!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ha! Madam! What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: O! My Child's ruin'd for ever!

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: That's as you please, Madam.
What says the Monster?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: That your Son, Madam, shall not be ruin'd; provided you will promise me not to Marry that old Fellow there, unless he signs my Settlement. In short, Madam, upon that Condition, I will not only resign your Son, and his Fortune into your Hands again; but will likewise engage to find a lawful Expedie t to disanul his Marriage too; which if you don't immediately comply with me shall be an eternal Secre • : So ev'n let him squander away his Estate as he pleases, I'll make a shift to glean a handsome livelyhood out on't I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, this is a very generous Proposal: Now if your Son's ruin'd, you are the occasion of it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: We all intreat for him.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Madam, I beseech you don't name it: I'll not believe a word he says, I dare swear this is all sham, a poor Pretence o • ly to get his Ends of me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Oones, Madam! You have nick'd it: But if it were true, let me alone to manage him, I know him by Experience: Why, the Dog had the Impudence t'other day to ask me to lend him Fifty Pound, and in less than a quarter of an hour I brought him down to three and six Pence.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: No! no! Devil! I will hear of nothing but Revenge. aside to Y. Ra.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Nay then, Madam, it's time for me to provide for my self; here comes one I an • ure will stand by me.

div.stage: Enter Mass Johnny with Lettice, and a Gentleman in a Parsons Habit.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Tall, lall, lall! (singing.) A hey! Where's Brother Father-in Law?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Hah! my little sprig of Lewdness, how doest thou?

sp.speaker: M. Joh.
sp.p: How do I? why I am Married Boy! How shou'd I do?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Give you Joy, Madam! (Saluting Lettice.)

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: What do I see? Undone! Ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Humh! the Parson there too! Nay then Mischief is not far off.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Well! but hark you John! how do my Mother, and you agree, what been't you Married yet?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: O Lord! Squire, no! nor am not like to be; she is just going to be Married to my Father.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Icod I thought as much! Did not I tell you, you did not know her? Did not I tell you so? look you Jahn there are two things she never kept in all her life, that is—a Fast day, and a promise! to my certain knowledge, her word is but wind, and Icod she no more values to break one, than t'other.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Well Squire! it shall never trouble me, as long as I suffer upon your account: For to tell you the truth, the real occasion of her Discarding me was my Friendly Promotion of your Marriage: But there's a very easie way to reward my service, which is that upon condition my Father will sign this Writing, you will generously condescend to choose him for your Guardian.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: I'll do't an'twere ten times more to serve you: lets see the Writings, I'll do't Icod.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: There Sir! (Gives him the Writings.)

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: (to the Maj.) Look you Sir! You Mr.—Mr. Jahn's Vather here, I don't know what your Name is not I: But if you think fit d'yee see! to sign this Paper, I'll make you my Guardian.—That's all I have to say to you,—so take, and look it over.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Let's see it my Dear Lad.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Madam, I am sensible a word from you wou'd finish the Business, if you will stand my Friend I am still ready to disanull your Son's Marriage.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Alas! Heav'n knows I wou'd do it were there but a Possibility of your making your words true.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Madam! This Gentleman's Word and Honour shall be your Security.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Madam, I will engage for him.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Em. & Ol.
sp.p: And all of us.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Well! I find it's in vain to contend with him: Therefore Dear Major, sign it immediately, and from this moment all I have is yours.

O Madam! a word from you wou'd make me do ten times more; for the six Thousand Pound in ready Gold, and Jewels, runs in my Head confoundedly, I long to be at it: And as for Jacky, I reckon within four or five days I shall nick off this Annuity again at the Groom Porters; and so have at him. (He signs the Writing.)—So! there Charles, (Gives it to Longville.) You are engag'd to see him perform Articles 〈◊〉 she keeps his word, much good may do him.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Come Squire, are you contented this Gentleman shall Marry your Mother, and be your Guardian?

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Yes I be!—and so let him take my Writings, and pray don't 'ce Cheat me now! It's for Jahn's sake I tell you that.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Well, Madam, now to dissipate your Fears, in one word I must acquaint you, that your Son Johnny, and my Brother Elect, is not Married.

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: How not Married! you over joy me, Sir, make it appear, and you shall never want a Friend in me.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: What a Devil makes you raise such a Lye now?

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Prithee my Dear Squire don't interrupt us.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: I will 'terrupt you then, what do you shove me for? I be Married, so I bee! yes I bee! I bee! (Raising his Voice.)

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Silence! Come Mrs. Lettice, pray satisfie my Lady, and this Good Company concerning your suspected Marriage with this young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: Ay, ay, do, let her speak, withal my heart Icod! see! who will Prove the Lyar Mr. Jahn.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Well Squire! since I must speak then, I declare before my Lady, and this Good Company, that I neither am your Wife, nor ever will be.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Now Sir, what say you.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: I say she lyes—she is my Wife, and you know it well enough, and the Parson knows it too: What a Rope did I give him two Crown Pieces for!

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Ounds! I don't know what to make of this Business: One says ay! and t'other says no; Prithee Dear Domine put us out of our Pain, come Answer to the Question, are they Married, or not?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I must confess, Sir, at your Son's Request, I did Mumble over a Parcel of Words, that satisfied the young Squire, as well as if they had been Canonical: But to convince yon, that it was not in my Power to injure him that way, I am no Parson: But his Humble Servant and Kinsman Ned Friendly.

sp.speaker: L. Man.
sp.p: Mr. Friendly! Dear Sir, this was kindly done of you.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Madam, upon my Knees I beg your Ladyship Pardon, I must confess I had like to have married my young Master, had not Mr. Rakish's Care prevented it: But he soon convinc'd me, what an uneasie Life I must have expected from your Ladyship, and the rest of his Relations: But to satisfie you, Madam, That I never intend to have any Thoughts of him as long as I live, Mr. Rakish has been pleas'd to give me his Bond to pay me Forty Pound a Year during Life, provided I immediately leave the Town, and go and live with my Friends in the Country, which I faithfully promise your Ladiship to perform to Morrow Morning; and so dear Squire farewell! Pray wish me a good Journey, as I do you a better Wife, and many happy days.

sp.speaker: M. Jo.
sp.p: (half crying.) What will you leave me now? Are these your Tricks? Pray give me my Purse agen, since you won't Marry me, young Gentlewoman, you shall have no fine Cloaths, I'll tell you that! Give me my Pa ••• wull ye?

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Sirrah, let her alone, That Purse you Purloyn'd from me, and she shall keep it: Nay, to reward her Honesty, I'll present her with this Ring, as an earnest of my future Kindness.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: I humbly thank your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: What! And so I am to be cheated out of my Money too! This is all long of you—Mr. Jahn! (crys.)

sp.speaker: Y. Ra
sp.p: Come! come! Squire don't be troubled, when you want Money, come to me; in the mean time hark you in your Ear: I have as pretty a young Wench in my Eye for you—She will be in Town in two or three days— Mum!

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: P •• a! What do I care for a Wench! If I can't have her, when I have a mind to it! Here I thought to have had such a Night on't now! and now the Parson has said Grace, you tell me I shall go to Dinner a Month hence.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Why then, to stay your Stomack, go with me to the last Act of the Play, and I'll show you one that ne'r deny'd a Man twice in her Life.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: Ay so you say! But I warrant she will pluck me by the Hair, if I offer to meddle with her.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Come! Come! I will stand your Friend, observe what I say to your Mother—Madam, your Son is sensible of his Error, and desires your Ladyship will take him into Favour agen. And from this time he has promis'd never to disobey you.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: No! no more I won't indeed Mother, if you will but let me go with Mr. Jahn to see the Play to Night?

sp.speaker: L. Ma.
sp.p: Well be Obedient for the future, and no reasonable freedom shall be deny'd you.

sp.speaker: M. J.
sp.p: O Lord! Thank you dear Mother, Icod I am glad we are Friends agen! Lord! I am so glad!—Won't 'e buss me Mother. Kisses.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra
sp.p: So! Now I hope we are all Friends.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Well Majo • ! Are you satisfied that your Son has Perform'd his Articles? Shall I deliver him the Writing?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: O! By all means! Upon my word Major he has deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Why the Dog has done something for't, that's the Truth on't. Tho' I will lay fifty Pound, I have seven to four upon it, before to morrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Well Sir! (to the Maj.) Now I wish you Joy; and thank you for my Settlement, tho' it's an hundred to one but the World will think you have given it me because you coud not help it.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: Ay! And I warrant Jackey, they will be apt to say too, that thou art as well satisfied as if I had given it thee with a good Will.

sp.speaker: Y. Ra.
sp.p: Ay Sir! People will out with their bold Truths now and then; but come Gentlemen, How shall we dispose of our selves this Afternoon? What think you of the Play?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
With all my Heart! And after that, I beg my House may Entertain us; where we'll reflect at leisure upon the happy Changes in our Fortune: But Yours, and Mine, my Lord, are owing both to the successess Wit of one inveterate Woman: From whence we may observe, that Virtue ever is the secret Care of Providence: Had Leonora been less my Enemy, I never cou'd have prov'd my self so near a Friend: Her plotted Injuries to me, are now my Glory, and her own Dishonor:
And may the blest Event this Truth Record,
That Good a • d Evil Actions are their own Reward.
